(Thats despite his knack for eliciting groans on Twitter.)

title: Justice Dept. Restores Use of Consent Decrees for Police Abuses
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday rescinded a Trump administration policy that curbed the use of consent decrees to address police misconduct, as the Justice Department prepared to step up its role in investigating allegations of racist and illegal behavior by police forces amid a nationwide outcry about the deaths of Black people at the hands of officers.

title: Pregnant women in Britain will be offered Covid-19 vaccines.
description: Pregnant women in Britain are now eligible to receive a Covid-19 vaccine, British health authorities announced on Friday, citing data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that showed that about 90,000 pregnant women had been vaccinated in the United States without any health issues.

title: How I Tricked Myself Into Liking Running
description: Until last week, the only time Id finished a race was during Track and Field Day in fifth grade. By middle school, I was trying to figure out how to get out of gym class because it was too hard for me to run a mile. Sports, in general, were not my thing. Running, less so.

title: Its a National Embarrassment, Biden Says on Gun Violence
description: President Biden said on Friday that he was committed to passing gun control legislation and called on Senate Republicans to support a bill already passed by the House.

title: The Justice Department sues Roger Stone, a longtime Trump ally, alleging tax evasion.
description: The Justice Department filed a civil suit on Friday against Roger J. Stone, one of former President Donald J. Trumps most visible allies, for failure to pay nearly $2 million in federal income taxes.

title: Biden and Suga Agree U.S. and Japan Will Work Together on 5G
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan pledged on Friday to work jointly on the rapid development of 5G communications technologies to prevent one of Chinas leading companies from dominating the global market, a symbolic first move at shoring up an alliance that withered during the Trump administration.

title: Months Before Season, N.F.L. and Players Clash Over Pandemic Workouts
description: Five months before the regular season starts, the N.F.L. and its players are facing their first clash over playing in the pandemic, with players for nearly half of the teams vowing to skip voluntary off-season workouts.

title: Biden Wavers on Restricting Refugee Entry
description: WASHINGTON  The White House announced on Friday that President Biden would limit the number of refugees allowed into the United States this year to the historically low level set by the Trump administration, reversing an earlier promise to welcome more than 60,000 people fleeing war and persecution.

title: Quotation of the Day: The Contradiction That Doomed Americas Mission in Afghanistan
description: You cant actually parachute in a consolidated state. But thats what we were trying to do.

title: Corrections: April 17, 2021
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about New Yorkers whose houses were flooded with sewage in 2019 misstated the percentages of homeownership among New Yorkers of different ethnic and racial groups in 2018. The percentages given referred to homeownership within those communities, not to homeownership in the city over all. That year, 44 percent of Asian households and 43 percent of white households owned their homes, while the same was true for just 27 percent of Black households and 17 percent of Latino households.

title: U.S. and Japan Pledge to Advance Democratic Values
description: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House, where they pledged to work together to counter authoritarianism and advance shared democratic norms.

title: Something Opened With a Click
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Todays grid has one of the most disarming set of misdirects that Ive seen in a while. As a paper solver I would have left a couple of incorrect letters in the grid and went on with my day if it werent for having to write this write-up, and I imagine that plenty of online solvers had to run through the alphabet a couple of times, on entries with four and five letters, no less. Leslie Rogers is fairly new; her last puzzle was the clever one on daylight saving time in March, and this is only her second themeless. I think its a good one  lively and original, with seven debuts tucked in throughout.

title: Hundreds March in Chicago, Protesting Police Shooting of Adam Toledo, 13
description: CHICAGO  Hundreds of people marched through the Logan Square neighborhood in Chicago on Friday evening, calling for overhauls to the citys police department after the fatal shooting of 13-year-old Adam Toledo by a police officer in March.

title: In a Spasm of Violence, Indianapolis Faces the Countrys Latest Mass Shooting
description: INDIANAPOLIS  He appeared in the parking lot after dark  a hooded figure with a gun who immediately began spraying bullets in every direction.

title: Rays Continue Their Domination of Struggling Yankees
description: Brandon Lowe hit a two-run double in the first inning off opener Nick Nelson, and the Tampa Bay Rays kept up their domination of the Yankees with an 8-2 win Friday night that set off frustrated fans who caused a brief interruption.

title: Pseudonymous Boschs First Book Under His Real Name
description: THE ANTI-BOOKBy Raphael Simon

title: When Harry Met Harry
description: HOUDINI AND MEBy Dan Gutman

title: Realtors Want to Sell You a Home. Their Trade Group Backs Evicting Others.
description: Some of the same people in charge of selling you a home have sued to make it easier to evict people from one.

title: How a Common Air Freshener Can Result in a High-Stakes Traffic Stop
description: Phil Colbert was on his way to meet his father for lunch before his shift at an Arizona auto dealership in 2019 when he saw the flashing lights of a sheriffs patrol car in his mirror. He made sure his hands were on the steering wheel, planted at 10 and 2 as his parents had taught him, and asked why he had been stopped.

title: In a Changing Boston, a New Mayor Challenges the Police
description: BOSTON  Three weeks after her swearing-in as acting mayor of Boston, Kim Janey was enjoying a sort of honeymoon, enacting feel-good policies like forgiving library fines and basking in the spotlight that came with her status as the citys first Black and first female mayor.

title: Least Vaccinated U.S. Counties Have Something in Common: Trump Voters
description: A Times analysis found that willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were both lower, on average, in counties that voted red in the 2020 presidential election.

title: In The Middle of Chaos: Living With the Daunte Wright Protests at the Front Door
description: For the past several nights, Ebonie McMillan and her children watched in real time as protests over the death of Daunte Wright turned violent. Heres what they saw.

title: The Republican Retreat on World Affairs
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Scrutiny of William and Harrys relationship hovers over the funeral.
description: Almost 24 years ago, the world watched as a pair of brothers, ages 15 and 12, walked a mile through London behind a horse-drawn carriage holding their mothers coffin.

title: Philips funeral nods to a life of service and his unwavering loyalty to the queen.
description: Queen Elizabeth II, wearing a black mask and seated alone, said goodbye to her husband of more than 73 years, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, at his funeral on Saturday at St. Georges Chapel in Windsor Castle.

title: Can Covid Research Help Solve the Mysteries of Other Viruses?
description: Barie Carmichael lost her sense of taste and smell while traveling in Europe. She remembers keeping a dinner date at a Michelin-starred restaurant but tasting nothing. I didnt have the heart to tell my host, she said.

title: Danica Roem, a Pathbreaking Lawmaker, on the Fight for Trans Rights
description: While Republican-controlled legislatures across the country are passing a flurry of bills aimed at limiting transgender rights and medical care, Virginia is going the opposite way.

title: When Her Mother Died, She Found Solace at a Korean Grocery
description: After an hour of discussing her mother, the afterlife and the shamelessness sometimes required in producing art, Michelle Zauner adjusted her video camera to show her Bushwick apartment. Her coffee table, suddenly in view, was covered with Jolly Pong Cereal Snack, NongShim Shrimp Crackers, Lotte Malang Cow Milk Candies and other Asian junk food.

title: Democrats Aim to Revive a Campaign Finance Watchdog
description: WASHINGTON  Even in a dysfunctional capital, the Federal Election Commission has long stood out for monumental dysfunction.

title: Rising Debt, Falling Income: How to Dig Out
description: Angie Barajas taught special education and bilingual classes in El Paso high schools for 25 years. But after caring for two ailing family members, Ms. Barajas slid from a stable middle-class life into bankruptcy court.

title: 100 Days Without Trump on Twitter: A Nation Scrolls More Calmly
description: That soothing sound that Gary Cavalli hears emanating from Twitter these days? It is the sound of silence  specifically, the silence of former President Donald J. Trump.

title: These Countries Did Well With Covid. So Why Are They Slow on Vaccines?
description: All through last year, as first Europe and then the United States suffered catastrophically high coronavirus infections and deaths, Pacific Rim countries staved off disaster through an array of methods. South Korea tested widely. Australia and New Zealand locked down. In Japan, people donned masks and heeded calls to isolate.

title: One Way to Get People Off the Streets: Buy Hotels
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The inside of the van was lined with plastic. The driver was masked and ready to go. There was a seat for just one passenger.

title: A War Is Ending. A Pennsylvania Town Exhales.
description: CANONSBURG, Pa.  Every year, Eric Miller brought his son Aidan to the famous Fourth of July parade in Canonsburg, an hourslong procession that draws tens of thousands of spectators, with lawn chairs set out along the route days ahead of time.

title: Myanmars Protesters Face Down the Military With Slingshots and Rocks
description: Every day, when Ko Win Kyaw goes out to demonstrate against the Myanmar military, he carries his slingshot and a supply of rocks as ammunition. It is little help against the armys overwhelming firepower, but he says it gives him confidence and a way to strike back.

title: Throughout Trial Over George Floyds Death, Killings by Police Mount
With attendance limited to 30, a look at who was at the funeral.
description: Amid coronavirus restrictions, Britain has had to adjust how it grieves over the past year. And with current rules allowing for just 30 people at funerals, the royal family scaled back plans for the service for Prince Philip.

title: Crypto Is Minting Lobbyists
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: As Covid Death Toll Passes 3 Million, a Weary World Takes Stock
description: Three million lives: That is roughly equivalent to losing the population of Berlin, Chicago or Taipei. The scale is so staggering that it sometimes begins to feel real only in places like graveyards.

title: A vaccine scare ripples around the world: The week in Covid-19 news.
description: Safety worries about the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccines in the United States and Europe have reverberated around the world, undercutting faith in two sorely needed shots and threatening to prolong the coronavirus pandemic in poorer countries that cannot afford to be choosy about vaccines. With new infections surging on nearly every continent, signs that the vaccination drive is in peril are emerging, most disconcertingly in the continent of Africa.

title: The Moral Case for Buying Erling Haaland
description: As the danger bubbled to the surface, there was an audible intake of breath among Manchester Citys substitutes. Once it had passed, a few seconds later, as they exchanged glances  of admiration, of relief  came a little murmur of appreciation. In the silence of the stadium, you could hear the sounds of game recognizing game.

title: How to Help a Grieving Neighbor
description: Q: I live in a close-knit Upper East Side rental building, where neighbors trade phone numbers and collect one anothers packages. The woman who lives below me lost her husband in August after an illness. Since then, Ive heard her wailing, talking and cursing to herself, clearly in despair. The neighbor below her also can hear the noises, but we dont know how to approach this. I have offered the widow help with errands when I see her, so she knows were here for her, but she declines, and I dont think that would really help anyway. Any advice on how we can handle this?

title: In counties that voted for Trump, fewer people are getting vaccinated.
description: The New York Times examined survey and vaccine administration data for nearly every U.S. county and found that both willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were lower, on average, in counties where a majority of residents voted to re-elect former President Donald J. Trump in 2020.

title: Shine a Spotlight on Peas
description: Asparagus and rhubarb steal much of the spotlight this time of year, leaving the modest pea waiting in the wings. Now is its time to shine  in Melissa Clarks pasta primavera, our most popular recipe of the week, or in this recipe for risi e bisi, the latest from Gabrielle Hamilton. Even its cousin, the sugar snap pea, deserves some time in the sun with Melissa Clarks spiced salmon with sugar snap peas and red onion (above). Youll find plenty more dishes packed with spring flavors in our collection of the most popular New York Times Cooking recipes of the week.

title: A Catholic Order Pledged $100 Million to Atone for Taking Part in the Slave Trade. Some Descendants Want a New Deal.
description: Ronda Thompson got the astounding news in a text from her sister. The Jesuits, the prominent order of Catholic priests that had enslaved her ancestors, had vowed to raise $100 million to atone for participating in the American slave trade.

title: Be Kind Whenever Possible. It Is Always Possible.
description: To the Editor:

title: I Have Read Thousands of Rsums, and I Have Some Advice
description: In the last decade, I have revised 3,000 rsums while working as a college career adviser. Here is my advice: The strongest will fit on a single page. Exceptions are few. An 8.5-by-11-inch sheet of letter paper fits about 700 words. So be efficient. Recruiters often say they spend six seconds reviewing the average candidate. Are you worth seven?

title: Im the Head of Planned Parenthood. Were Done Making Excuses for Our Founder.
description: We need to talk about Margaret Sanger.

title: Why Anti-Abortion Catholics Should Get Vaccinated
description: America is rapidly approaching the point where demand, not supply, is the limiting factor of our vaccine rollout. Our job now is hearing out the worries of vaccine-hesitant friends and trying to assuage their concerns. My fellow Catholics are one group in need of assurance.

title: Post-Merkel Germany May Be Shaded Green
description: Whatever government fills the vacuum in Germany after Chancellor Angela Merkel will be tinged with green.

title: What Will Happen When Americans Start Having Sex Again?
description: Dr. Hilary Renos eyes widened as she scanned the waiting room at the St. Louis County Sexual Health Clinic in Missouri, where shes the medical director. She was used to seeing a swath of humanity parked in those plastic chairs: middle-aged men secretly screening after a tryst; college students making a post-hookup pit stop; teenagers, fresh in love, testing together before taking the next step. But now, in the spring of 2019, every seat was filled, with more patients leaning up against the walls. How, she thought to herself, can we possibly keep up?

title: The Covid-19 Plasma Boom Is Over. What Did We Learn From It?
description: Scott Cohen was on a ventilator struggling for his life with Covid-19 last April when his brothers pleaded with Plainview Hospital on Long Island to infuse him with the blood plasma of a recovered patient.

title: Hundreds Protest Fatal Police Shooting of 13-Year-Old in Chicago
description: Demonstrators in Chicago marched on Friday evening, calling for police reforms in response to the killing last month of Adam Toledo, one of the youngest people killed by the police in Illinois in years.

title: Biden Ditches the Generals, Finally
description: WASHINGTON  Afghanistan has a complicated relationship with time. And America has a complicated relationship with revenge.

title: After Bullying Reports, Scott Rudin Says Hell Step Back From Broadway
description: Scott Rudin, a powerful Broadway producer facing renewed accusations of bullying, apologized Saturday for troubling interactions with colleagues and said he would step aside from active participation in his current shows.

title: Fund-Raising Surged for Republicans Who Sought to Overturn the Election
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans who were the most vocal in urging their followers to come to Washington on Jan. 6 to try to reverse President Donald J. Trumps loss, pushing to overturn the election and stoking the grievances that prompted the deadly Capitol riot, have profited handsomely in its aftermath, according to new campaign data.

title: Chicago, Long Riven Over Police Conduct, Reels Anew After Shooting of 13-Year-Old
description: CHICAGO  Another killing by a police officer. Another emotional mayor trying to soothe the city. Another burst of protests, vows for change, pleas for calm.

title: Rusty Young, Country-Rock Pioneer, Is Dead at 75
description: Rusty Young, a founding member of the popular country-rock group Poco and a key figure in establishing the pedal steel guitar as an integral voice in the West Coast rock of the late 1960s and 70s, died on Wednesday at his home in Davisville, Mo. He was 75.

title: Biden Choice for Justice Dept.s No. 2 Is Seen as a Consensus Builder
description: WASHINGTON  Lisa Monaco was President Barack Obamas top counterterrorism adviser when she was handed an intractable problem: Fix the administrations ineffective response to the kidnappings of Americans by Islamic State fighters, which had prompted outcries from victims families, without changing the governments refusal to make concessions to terrorists.

title: After a Year of Turmoil, Elite Universities Welcome More Diverse Freshman Classes
description: Jianna Curbelo attends a career-focused public high school in New York City, works at McDonalds and lives in the Bronx with her unemployed mother, who did not graduate from college.

title: Prince Philip Is Laid to Rest in a Somber 50-Minute Ceremony
description: LONDON  His coffin borne on a military green Land Rover that he had helped design, Prince Philip was laid to rest on Saturday at Windsor Castle in an austere, meticulously choreographed funeral that captured his steely role in Britains royal family and offered a solemn glimpse of its uncertain future.

title: Variety: Special Cryptic
description: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD  Today we have a puzzle from a prolific setter, or constructor, making his New York Times debut, although hes quite a capo di cryptic in England. If you have ever solved a puzzle by Mudd in the Financial Times, Dada in The Telegraph, Mara in The Times (U.K.  requires a subscription) or Punk in The Independent, then youve already tried your hand at a John Halpern creation.

title: Highest French Court Rules Killer of Jewish Woman Cannot Stand Trial
description: PARIS  The highest court in France has ruled that the man who killed a Jewish woman in 2017 in an anti-Semitic frenzy cannot stand trial because he was in a state of acute mental delirium brought on by his consumption of cannabis.

title: Debating Exit From Afghanistan, Biden Rejected Generals Views
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden used his daily national security briefing on the morning of April 6 to deliver the news that his senior military leaders suspected was coming. He wanted all American troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11, the 20th anniversary of the attacks on New York and the Pentagon.

title: Biden Administration Ends Limits on Use of Fetal Tissue for Research
description: The Biden administration on Friday lifted restrictions on the use of fetal tissue for medical research, reversing rules imposed in 2019 by President Donald J. Trump.

title: Virus cases and hospitalizations rise sharply in Pennsylvania, as dozens of other states see high caseloads.
description: Coronavirus cases and hospitalizations are surging in Pennsylvania, as state officials warn of the impact of trends seen across the country: increased travel, relaxing restrictions and the spread of more contagious virus variants.

title: Ron DeSantis Is the Republican Autopsy
description: After the Republican Party suffered a surprising (well, to Republicans) defeat in the 2012 election, the Republican National Committee famously commissioned an autopsy that tried to analyze how the party had fallen short. It made a range of recommendations, but they were distilled by the headlines  and the wishful thinking of certain party elites  into a plan for the G.O.P. to win back the presidency mostly by shifting left on immigration.

title: Make Tax-Dodging Companies Pay for Bidens Infrastructure Plan
description: American companies and companies that make money in the United States are not paying enough money in taxes. Even as profits have soared, tax payments have declined. Fifty-five of the nations largest corporations  including FedEx, Nike and the agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland  paid nothing in federal income taxes in 2020, despite collectively reporting more than $40 billion in profits, according to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy.

title: Swiss Billionaire Is Said to End His Bid for Tribune Publishing
description: The Swiss billionaire Hansjrg Wyss, who seemingly came out of nowhere last month to make a serious offer for Tribune Publishing, a major newspaper chain, has decided to take himself out of the bidding, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Peloton Fights Back Against U.S. Warnings of Treadmill Dangers
description: The exercise bike company Peloton fought back on Saturday after a federal agency warned that those with children at home should stop using the companys Tread+ treadmills.

title: Aleksei Navalny Needs His Doctors
description: Aleksei Navalnys wife, doctor and colleagues have sounded an anguished alarm that the incarcerated Kremlin critics health is rapidly deteriorating and his heart could stop any minute. They and many other supporters of Mr. Navalny are demanding that his doctors be immediately allowed to see and treat him.

title: How Helen McCrory Shone, Even in a Haze of Mystery
description: Selfishly, my first feelings on hearing that the uncanny British actress Helen McCrory had died at 52 were of personal betrayal. We were supposed to have shared a long and fruitful future together, she and I. Thered be me on one side of the footlights and her on the other, as she unpacked the secrets of the human heart with a grace and ruthlessness shared by only a few theater performers in each generation.

title: Liam Scarlett, Choreographer Accused of Sexual Misconduct, Dies at 35
description: Liam Scarlett, a British choreographer who won early acclaim both at home and internationally for his ballets, died on Friday at his home in Ipswich, England. He was 35.

title: Seeing the queen alone adds a painful note for many watching from home.
description: She was utterly alone.

title: In a bid to curb the virus, Zimbabwe releases hundreds of prisoners.
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Zimbabwe released at least 320 prisoners from its jails on Saturday to ease congestion in the countrys notoriously overcrowded jails as a second wave of the coronavirus devastates the country.

title: Denis Donoghue, Humanist Literary Critic, Dies at 92
description: Denis Donoghue, an Irish academic whose wide-ranging literary tastes, erudite analysis of poets like T.S. Eliot and William Butler Yeats, and fierce aversion to the impositions of postmodern theory earned him a reputation as one of the last great humanist critics, died on April 6 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 92.

title: A Rare Find
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  A rare find, indeed! We meet a new constructor today from Sweden, a restaurant worker who hasnt yet visited the United States, although he has been solving American crossword puzzles for some time (speed-solving, I should say, with a Sunday personal best time of 10:36). This is according to Will Shortzs print introduction, which ends in Mr. Shortz declaring, Im honestly in awe (concerning this grid as well as the context of its constructor).

title: Ontario, hit with a virus surge, backtracks on sweeping new police powers.
description: Just a day after extending and expanding its stay-at-home orders, Ontario  Canadas most populous province  limited sweeping new powers that it had granted to the police to enforce the mandates in an effort to curb rising case numbers and hospitalizations.

title: The shooting in Indianapolis adds to a grim toll of workplace violence in the U.S.
description: The man who opened fire at a FedEx facility in Indianapolis late Thursday, fatally shooting eight people and injuring at least seven others, was a former employee at the facility, a spokesman for FedEx said.

title: Indianapolis police chief says gunman bought weapons legally despite earlier warning.
description: Brandon Hole, the 19-year-old who the police say fatally shot eight people at a FedEx facility on Thursday night, legally purchased two semiautomatic rifles he used in the attack more than six months earlier, according to the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.

title: FedEx Gunman Bought 2 Rifles After Police Seized His Shotgun, Chief Says
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Brandon Hole, the 19-year-old man who the police say fatally shot eight people at a FedEx facility on Thursday night, legally purchased two semiautomatic rifles he used in the attack just a few months after the police seized a shotgun from him, the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department said on Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day: Deadly Run-Ins With the Police Show No Pause
description: Its just another example of a nothing offense escalated to lethality.

title: Czechs Blame 2014 Blasts at Ammunition Depots on Elite Russian Spy Unit
description: The Czech Republic on Saturday blamed a series of mysterious 2014 explosions at Czech ammunition depots on an elite unit of Russias military intelligence service  a group that Britain has linked to a 2018 attack with a nerve agent on a former Russian spy in Salisbury, England.

title: Jacob deGrom Fans Nine in a Row as Mets Split Doubleheader
description: DENVER  Jacob deGrom struck out nine straight batters against Colorado on Saturday, falling one shy of matching Tom Seavers major league record.

title: A Window Into a Changed America
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Despite Tensions, U.S. and China Agree to Work Together on Climate Change
description: SEOUL  The United States and China have said they will fight climate change with the seriousness and urgency that it demands by stepping up efforts to reduce carbon emissions, a rare demonstration of cooperation amid escalating tensions over a raft of other issues.

title: Bake Bread and Hang Out With Whales
description: Here is a sampling of the weeks events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

title: Listen to a Changing Planet, Through These 5 Climate Podcasts
description: Giving climate change a worthy amount of attention can seem a daunting task. The scope of the problem is colossal; the obstacles to equitable solutions myriad. Yet we know the time for ignoring global warming has long passed. This Earth Day (Thursday), make a resolution to learn more about our collective planetary problems, along with possible solutions in the form of audio. Theres a sea of informative climate podcasts out there  in fact, a grass-roots movement has issued an open letter challenging Apple Podcasts to add a climate category to its many classifications  but these five audio journeys of climate storytelling are all fabulous places to start.

title: Prepare Your Patio for the Season
description: The weather is turning the corner, and that means one thing for certain: Its patio season. Before you resurrect the outdoor space of your dreams, though, give your patio furniture the spring cleaning it deserves. Heres how to get your furniture ready.

title: Banish Anxiety About Your Post-Lockdown Looks
description: Re-entry into pre-social distancing life is going to be such a joy. Re-entry into nonstretchy pants? Maybe not so much.

title: How Safe Are You From Covid When You Fly?
description: As vaccines become widely available and restrictions are eased, millions of people are flying again, raising questions about just how safe it is now to board a flight.

title: Corrections: April 18, 2021
description: An article on Page 15 this weekend about play reading groups describes incorrectly the type of work that donors to the Playwrights Realm could pay to act in. They could commission new plays or pay a smaller fee to act in a previously written play.

title: Build the Whole World With Your Hands (and Some Newspaper)
description: With the 51st anniversary of Earth Day approaching, many people will be celebrating the planet and focusing on what they can do to protect it. One way to remind yourself of Earths beauty is to make a light-up globe  from recycled newspaper, of course.

title: By the Time We Reached Main Street, I Had Lost Sight of Him
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Oscars Are a Week Away, but How Many Will Watch?
description: LOS ANGELES  Neither intimate looks into stars living rooms nor scantily clad pop stars performing provocative hits have been able to stop audiences from tuning out award shows this year. The ratings for the Grammys were down by 53 percent. The Golden Globes plummeted by more than 60.

title: How the Tiny Kingdom of Bhutan Out-Vaccinated Most of the World
description: THIMPHU, Bhutan  The Lunana area of Bhutan is remote even by the standards of an isolated Himalayan kingdom: It covers an area about twice the size of New York City, borders far western China, includes glacial lakes and some of the worlds highest peaks, and is inaccessible by car.

title: George Floyd, Indianapolis, Spring Migration: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: The Free World Explains How Culture Heated Up During the Cold War
description: In the spring of 1999, Louis Menand taught a class called Art and Thought of the 1960s at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He assigned Malcolm X, Joan Didion, Portnoys Complaint. Toward the end of the semester, he told his students he was thinking of writing a book about the 60s.

title: After Green Rush, Canadas Legal Pot Suppliers Are Stumbling
description: EXETER, Ontario  The mayor of the largely rural community of South Huron, Ontario, was looking forward to an employment boom when a marijuana producer used its soaring stock value to buy an enormous greenhouse on the edge of the municipalitys largest town.

title: Afghan Women Fear the Worst, Whether War or Peace Lies Ahead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Farzana Ahmadi watched as a neighbor in her village in northern Afghanistan was flogged by Taliban fighters last month. The crime: Her face was uncovered.

title: One America News Network Stays True to Trump
description: Months after the inauguration of President Biden, One America News Network, a right-wing cable news channel available in some 35 million households, has continued to broadcast segments questioning the validity of the 2020 presidential election.

title: Shooting at Bar Near Kenosha, Wis., Leaves at Least 3 Dead
description: Three people were killed and three more were hospitalized after a shooting at a bar early Sunday in Somers, Wis., near Kenosha, the latest instance of gun violence in a nation where such bloodshed has grown wearyingly commonplace.

title: The Week in Business: Lets Go Shopping
description: Good morning. The economy is showing more signs of recovery  jobs are coming back, the stock market is up (again) and people are spending money. Heres the latest in business and tech news for the week ahead. Stay safe out there.  Charlotte Cowles

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 19, 2021
The Sunday Read: Voices Carry
description: The Skagit Valley choir last sang together on the evening of March 10, 2020. This rehearsal, it would turn out, was one of the first documented superspreader events of the pandemic. Of the 61 choristers who attended practice that night, 53 developed coronavirus symptoms. Two later died.

title: Top European Soccer Teams Form Breakaway League
description: LONDON  A dozen of the worlds richest and most storied soccer clubs on Sunday announced that they had formed a breakaway European club competition that would, if it comes to fruition, upend the structures, economics and relationships that have bound global soccer for nearly a century.

title: California Beach Seized in 1924 From a Black Family Could Be Returned
description: Nearly a century after a Southern California city shuttered a beach resort owned by a Black couple, the city, county and state are still reckoning over how to right past wrongs.

title: Covid in the Future
description: David Leonhardts popular morning briefing, exclusively for NYT Audio.

title: What the Heck are NFTs? Lets Ask Beeple.
description: On Sway, Kara Swisher asks the artist about whether his work is actually worth $69 million, and whether non-fungible tokens are the next new asset class, or all hype.

title: Shes 18 and developed blood clots in her brain after a J&J vaccine. Heres what happened.
description: An 18-year-old woman was stricken with severe headaches, vomiting, seizures, confusion and weakness in one arm early this month, strokelike symptoms that doctors at a Nevada hospital were shocked to see in someone so young.

title: Airport vaccinations are just a flight away. To Alaska.
description: To some, Alaskas announcement that it would try to entice travelers by offering Covid-19 vaccinations at its airports might signal the states plucky resolve and determination to revive a tourism industry that has been devastated by the pandemic.

title: Asian-American Artists, Now Activists, Push Back Against Hate
description: Early in the pandemic, word started to travel among Asian-American artists: racist attacks were on the rise. Jamie Chan told a fellow artist, Kenneth Tam, about getting kicked out of an Uber pool ride by the driver who noticed her sniffling. Anicka Yi, an artist based in New York, called Christine Y. Kim, a curator at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, to talk about being spit at on a Manhattan street; Kim, in turn, recounted being accosted in a Whole Foods parking lot.

title: Aleksei Navalnys Health in Prison Is Dire, His Doctors Say
description: MOSCOW  The personal doctors of Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned Russian opposition leader, sharply escalated their warnings over the weekend about his health failing from a hunger strike, the lingering effects of an attempted poisoning with a chemical weapon and what they said was ill treatment in prison.

title: Cubicle Please!
description: Working from home has its perks, but some groups suffer from big drawbacks.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. My colleague Margaux Laskey introduced me to Mississippi Roast (above). I wrote about the dish for The Times a short while later and, five years on, I still hear from people who make it monthly, sometimes as written and sometimes with gravy packets, sometimes with pork and often with venison. Its the sort of flavor bomb that makes for a terrific dinner and great sandwiches with the leftovers on a following day. I think of it as a near-perfect Sunday supper, the kind that can simmer away all afternoon in a slow cooker or above a low flame on the stove, while you watch sports or read or prepare things for the freezer ahead of nights when you know youre not going to want to start dinner from scratch.

title: Fauci says he expects a decision Friday on whether the U.S. can resume using Johnson & Johnsons vaccine.
description: A decision about whether to resume administering the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine should come this Friday, when an expert panel that is advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is scheduled to meet, according to Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nations leading infectious disease expert.

title: Alex Joness Podcasting Hecklers Face Their Foils Downward Slide
description: CHICAGO  Last year, Alex Jones supplied conspiratorial content to the leader of the free world. This month, he was shamed by a nun.

title: Modern-Day Unbelievers, and Believers
description: To the Editor:

title: What Joe Biden and I Saw After the U.S. Invaded Afghanistan
description: I was not surprised that Joe Biden decided to finally pull the plug on the U.S. presence in Afghanistan. Back in 2002 it was reasonable to hope that our invasion there to topple Osama bin Laden and his Taliban allies could be extended to help make that country a more stable, tolerant and decent place for its citizens  and less likely to host jihadist groups. But it was also reasonable to fear from the start that trying to graft a Western political culture onto such a deeply tribalized, male-dominated and Islamic fundamentalist culture like Afghanistans was a fools errand, especially when you factored in how much neighboring Pakistan never wanted us to succeed because it could wrench Afghanistan from Pakistans cultural and geopolitical orbit.

title: A Different Way of Thinking About Cancel Culture
description: In March, Alexi McCammond, the newly hired editor of Teen Vogue, resigned following backlash over offensive tweets shed sent a decade ago, beginning when she was 17. In January, Will Wilkinson lost his job as vice president for research at the center-right Niskanen Center for a satirical tweet about Republicans who wanted to hang Mike Pence. (Wilkinson was also suspended from his role as a Times Opinion contributor.)

title: 12 Years 6 Months 25 Days: A Long Journey Back to the Majors
description: During the Atlanta Braves 13-4 loss to the Chicago Cubs at Wrigley Field on Saturday, infielder Sean Kazmar Jr. entered the game in the fifth inning as a pinch-hitter, saw four pitches and grounded into a double play. The three-minute appearance may not seem like much, but it meant the world to Kazmar and his family. It was Kazmars first major league game since Sept. 23, 2008  a span of 4,589 days.

title: The Climate Threat Posed by Plastics
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel, a world leader in vaccinations, lifts its outdoor mask mandate.
description: JERUSALEM  Buoyed by its recent success in combating the coronavirus, Israel lifted its outdoor mask mandate on Sunday, while schools fully reopened for the first time since September.

title: A Bobcat Attacks, and a Husband Swings Into Action
description: Just before the bobcat attacked, the quiet subdivision where Happy and Kristi Wade live in Burgaw, N.C., was the very picture of suburban tranquillity.

title: Defund Facial Recognition
description: Im a second-generation Black activist, and Im tired of being spied on by the police.

title: From boardroom to bedroom: New Yorks empty office buildings and hotels may be ripe for conversion.
description: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.

title: As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?
description: In February, Illinois enacted a law that rewrote many of the states rules of policing, and mandated that officers wear body cameras. In March, New York City moved to make it easier for citizens to sue officers. This month, the Maryland legislature  which decades ago became the first to adopt a Law Enforcement Officers Bill of Rights  became the first to do away with it.

title: Revisiting the Unusual Celebrity of Stephen Hawking
description: HAWKING HAWKINGThe Selling of a Scientific CelebrityBy Charles Seife

title: Sinn Fein Leader Apologizes for 1979 Killing of Prince Philips Uncle
description: LONDON  Seeking to salve an old wound at a time of sorrow for Britains royal family, the political leader of the Irish republican movement apologized on Sunday for the 1979 assassination of Louis Mountbatten, an uncle of Prince Philip.

title: Pope Francis delivers his Sunday blessing to pilgrims in St. Peters Square for the first time in a month.
description: Pope Francis spoke to the faithful from his study overlooking St. Peters Square on Sunday, the first time he had done so in just over a month.

title: A Cubicle Never Looked So Good
description: What we lose when we have to work from home.

title: Go Ahead. Take a Nap.
description: Struggling at work? Daily naps may be the key to peak productivity.

title: Black Rob, Rapper Known for His Hit Single Whoa!, Dies at 52
description: Robert Ross, the rapper known as Black Rob, whose husky, seen-it-all voice powered turn-of-the-millennium hits like Whoa! and Can I Live for Bad Boy Records, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 52.

title: Marie Supikova, Survivor of Nazi Terror in Czech Village, Dies at 88
description: Marie Supikova, who survived the Nazis massacre and destruction of her Czech village and testified about those horrors at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials when she was 15, died on March 22 in Prague. She was 88.

title: Colorado health officials warn of a new surge as counties loosen virus restrictions.
description: Health officials in Colorado are warning about another wave of infections as new coronavirus cases in the state jump to levels not seen since January and as counties start to loosen virus restrictions.

title: Aiming at variants, France will limit and quarantine travelers from Brazil, Argentina, Chile and South Africa.
description: French authorities will tightly restrict who can travel to France from Brazil, Argentina, Chile and South Africa, and will impose a 10-day quarantine on those who do, in the hope of staving off worrisome coronavirus variants circulating in those countries, the government announced on Saturday.

title: Taking Over Victory Gardens to Make a Theater for All
description: CHICAGO  Ken-Matt Martin, the incoming artistic director of Victory Gardens Theater here, said he never has revealed this publicly before, but he has a Sankofa bird tattooed on his back.

title: Gustavo Dudamel Hasnt Conducted Much Opera. Thats OK.
description: The conductor Gustavo Dudamel has accomplished so much in his blazing career that its easy to forget hes only 40. The music world has wondered for a while what his future would hold beyond the Los Angeles Philharmonic, a hotbed of adventurousness where he has been the musical leader since 2009. Major orchestras around the world have pursued him. Anything seemed possible.

title: Train Crash in Egypt Kills at Least 11
description: A passenger train derailed Sunday north of Cairo, killing at least 11 people and injuring scores more, the Egyptian authorities said. It was the latest of several deadly rail accidents to hit the country in recent years.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Aleksei Navalny, the imprisoned Russian opposition leader who survived an attempted poisoning and is now in the third week of a hunger strike, could die at any moment, his personal doctors said.

title: CBS News Will Try to Reinvent Itself, Again
description: In May 2020, a few months after CBS Evening News relocated from its longtime Manhattan home to Washington  a move that perplexed some producers and cost millions  the third-ranked newscast finally seemed to be finding a groove.

title: Main Line From the Heart
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  You know how a random order like Dont press the red button makes you itch to press that button immediately, no matter what dire consequence awaits? Well, whatever you do, please dont read the Constructor Notes first. Dont do it. Do. Not. Scroll Down. To. The. Notes. Period!

title: My Second Phase of Adulthood
description: This weekend I attended my second funeral in about six months. The first was my oldest brothers. The second was for the mother of a college friend. Neither death was caused by the pandemic, but took place during it.

title: 2 Killed in Driverless Tesla Car Crash, Officials Say
description: Two men were killed in Texas after a Tesla they were in crashed on Saturday and caught fire with neither of the men behind the wheel, the authorities said.

title: In the Roaring Twenties, Ads Make a Comeback
description: If you wanted to sound smart at a media business conference or sell your start-up over the last couple of years, youd talk about the rise of digital subscriptions. Netflix and Spotify led the way in getting consumers to pay every month for their content, and The New York Times, The Washington Post and many others followed. By last week, everyone was hawking media subscriptions, from the owners of the SpongeBob SquarePants TV show ($5.99 a month) to the staid newswire Reuters ($35) to my friend Isaac who wanders aimlessly around New York ($7).

title: Fans Wait on Yankees to Show Up, but One Player Wont Be Back
description: The Yankees lost again on Sunday to Tampa Bay, 4-2, a drearily routine result in an oddly lopsided rivalry. The Rays pulled their usual pitching voodoo, with an opener drafted in the 45th round and a closer with no career saves. The pitcher who worked most of the game has one of the slowest fastballs in the sport.

title: What Snoop Doggs Success Says About the Book Industry
description: When bookstores across the United States closed last spring, Tyrrell Mahoney, the president of Chronicle Books, braced for disaster as she watched revenue plummet. Then, months into the crisis, Chronicle found an unlikely savior: the rapper Snoop Dogg and his two-year-old cookbook.

title: Outrage About European Super League Is Muffled by Our Cheers
description: Real Madrids players pumped fists and exchanged hugs. A scoreless tie at Liverpool on Wednesday night had assured that the Spanish club had taken what it saw as its rightful place in the semifinals of the Champions League. All of a sudden, a 14th European Cup title hung tantalizingly close.

title: In Indianapolis Shooting, a Red Flag That Never Flew
description: INDIANAPOLIS  They are the rare gun laws that attract bipartisan agreement  so-called red flag laws, which allow the authorities to temporarily take away guns from people declared by a judge to be too unstable to have them.

title: Stroman Dominates for Eight Innings in Win Over Rockies
description: DENVER  Marcus Stroman pitched eight innings of one-run ball and made a dazzling defensive play, catcher James McCann threw out Trevor Story as he attempted to steal second for the final out and the Mets beat the Colorado Rockies, 2-1, on Sunday.

title: A Climate Change Guide for Kids
description: The future could be bad, or it could be better. You can help decide.

title: Russia Expels 20 Czech Diplomats as Tensions Escalate
description: A day after the government of the Czech Republic blamed operatives from Russias military intelligence agency for a series of mysterious explosions at an ammunition depot in 2014 and expelled 18 Russian diplomats, the Russian government announced on Sunday that 20 Czech diplomats would be ejected in response.

title: Lesson of the Day: Bad Future, Better Future
description: This Lesson of the Day will help prepare students to participate in our live panel discussion about climate change, on April 22 at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

title: No Corrections: April 19, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 19, 2021.

title: Quotation of the Day: With Much to Lose, Afghan Women Fear Stifling Return to Past
description: All the time, women are the victims of mens wars. But they will be the victims of their peace, too.

title: Minnesota Governor Calls Alleged Assaults on Journalists Chilling
description: Tim Walz, the governor of Minnesota, on Sunday responded to reports that the states police officers had assaulted journalists covering the unrest in a Minneapolis suburb, saying, Apologies are not enough; it just cannot happen.

title: John Grisham Leaves the Courtroom for Basketball, and Sudan
description: There is a basketball term to describe the author John Grisham: volume shooter.

title: College Players Graduating to the N.H.L. Have a Chance for Longer Test Run
description: Each spring as college hockey seasons conclude, several top players  highly drafted underclassmen and free agents, for the most part  quickly progress to the professional ranks. But theres a bonus for those players this year.

title: N.F.L. Draft Process Adapts With the Pandemic
description: [Follow live updates from the first round of the N.F.L. draft.]

title: Vanessa Bryant Uses Her Platform to Battle the Powerful
description: For years, under the power dynamics of Los Angeles policing, many victims who have accused powerful law enforcement institutions of wrongdoing have found their charges batted aside or buried in bureaucratic inertia.

title: Why the Worst N.B.A. Player Is (Probably) Still Better Than You
description: Of the millions of people around the world who play basketball, fewer than 500 are in the N.B.A. at any given time. Fewer than 150 are in the W.N.B.A. Before retiring in 2012, Brian Scalabrine spent 11 seasons in the N.B.A., far more than the majority of players who have made it to that level. He won a championship as a reserve for the Boston Celtics in 2008. He is 6-foot-9 and roughly 250 pounds.

title: NASAs Mars Helicopter Completes First Flight on Another Planet
description: A small robotic helicopter named Ingenuity made space exploration history on Monday when it lifted off the surface of Mars and hovered in the wispy air of the red planet. It was the first machine from Earth ever to fly like an airplane or a helicopter on another world.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Aleksei Navalny, the imprisoned Russian dissident, could die at any moment, his personal doctors said. Mr. Navalny, who last year survived an attempted poisoning, is now in the third week of a hunger strike over his medical treatment.

title: Whats on TV This Week: The Oscars and a Greta Thunberg Documentary
description: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.

title: Word of the Day: lamentable
Democratic Ballot Order Is Revealed: 5 Takeaways From the Mayors Race
description: Much of the focus in the New York City mayoral race has been given to the eight best-known Democratic candidates, who lead in fund-raising and in early polling. But on the June 22 primary ballot, none of the eight will appear at the top; that honor will go to a more obscure candidate.

title: God Knows Whats Going to Happen: Minneapolis Braces for Verdict in Floyds Death
They Told Her Women Couldnt Join the Ambulance Corps. So She Started Her Own.
description: Charna Goldsmith, an E.M.T. with the group Ezras Nashim

title: The Fed Faces Criticism as It Wades Into Climate and Equity Issues
description: In mid-2019, Jerome H. Powell fielded a question from reporters that he often faced in those days: Were politics, and particularly a pressure campaign coming from Donald J. Trumps White House to cut interest rates, influencing the Federal Reserves policy stance?

title: Ray McGuire Wants to Show Hes Not Just the Wall Street Candidate
description: In the intensifying race for mayor of New York City, numerous endorsements have trickled out, but few with the star power of the one jointly given to Raymond J. McGuire last week: Jay-Z, Diddy and Nas.

title: A Cuba Without a Castro? A Country Steps Into the Unknown.
description: When Ral Castro retired as Cubas top leader Monday, he left a warning for a nation increasingly divided over the legacy of its Communist revolution: The choice at hand is continuity of the revolutions ideals, or defeat.

title: A Quiet Arms Race Is Rapidly Heating Up Between the Two Koreas
description: SEOUL  Pride and jealousy have driven North and South Korea to engage in propaganda shouting matches and compete over who could build a taller flagpole on their border. Now that one-upmanship is intensifying a much more dangerous side of their rivalry: the arms race.

title: Battle Over Super League Begins With Letters, Threats and Banners
description: LONDON  The superclubs have called in the lawyers. The president of European soccer has responded, calling the teams leaders snakes and liars. And the fans want no part of any of it.

title: Former Sheriffs Deputy Is Charged After Deadly Shooting in Austin
description: DALLAS  A former sheriffs deputy who was being sought after three people were fatally shot in Austin, Texas, on Sunday has been arrested and charged with capital murder, according to the police and jail records.

title: Neil deGrasse Tyson Thinks Science Can Reign Supreme Again
description: In the 1960s, while were going to the moon, you didnt need special programs to get people interested.

title: Should There Be Separate Social Media Apps for Children?
Emerging From the Pandemic With Acne, Facial Hair and Body Odor
description: A pediatrician friend saw a 10-year-old girl recently, for her yearly checkup. Like so many children (and so many adults) among us, she had gained a little extra weight over the past year, but she was fundamentally healthy. The mom says to me, You know, shes very self-conscious, shes developed over this last year, and none of her friends have, and it makes her so uncomfortable and it makes her sad, said the pediatrician, Dr. Terri McFadden, a professor of pediatrics at Emory University School of Medicine.

title: Tell Me the One About the Presidential Candidate Who Ran for Mayor
description: Bret Stephens: Gail, youre a New Yorker and Im now a former New Yorker, albeit one who is often in town. How are you feeling about the city these days? And do you have any preferences in the race to succeed Bill de Blasio?

title: Shes Taking Jeff Bezos to Task
description: Big Brother is watching. And hes biased.

title: Whats Behind the Growth in Alcohol Consumption?
description: American deaths from misuse of substances, including alcohol, have increased over the past two decades, but not uniformly across various demographic groups.

title: New York Spent $1.5 Billion on Its Convention Center. Will Anyone Come?
description: New York has just spent $1.5 billion to entice very large groups of people to gather under the same roof. When will that seem like a good idea again?

title: We Were Born to Be Wild
description: NASHVILLE  To get from my bedroom to the coffeepot every morning, I pass a bank of windows that overlooks two feeders and a birdbath. My early-morning habit is to stand there for a bit, starting the day with my avian neighbors. If its migration season, as it is now, I get my coffee and come back for a longer stay, just in case an exotic visitor has arrived during the night.

title: Why Political Sectarianism Is a Growing Threat to American Democracy
description: American democracy faces many challenges: New limits on voting rights. The corrosive effect of misinformation. The rise of domestic terrorism. Foreign interference in elections. Efforts to subvert the peaceful transition of power. And making matters worse on all of these issues is a fundamental truth: The two political parties see the other as an enemy.

title: The New Redlining Is Deciding Who Lives in Your Neighborhood
description: Housing segregation by race and class is a fountainhead of inequality in America, yet for generations, politicians have been terrified to address the issue. That is why it is so significant that President Biden has proposed, as part of his American Jobs Act, a $5 billion race-to-the-top competitive grants program to spur jurisdictions to eliminate exclusionary zoning and harmful land use policies.

title: My Daughter and I Are Trapped in Brazils Tragedy
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  From the balcony of my apartment, I can see an ambulance parking lot. For over a year now, my 2-year-old daughter and I have been monitoring  avidly, anxiously  the movements of the 10 ambulances parked there. Thats the sort of entertainment we have now.

title: With Knives Out Deal, Netflix Signals Its in the Franchise Business
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood let out a collective gasp this month when it was announced that Netflix had spent about $465 million to buy two sequels to the quirky surprise 2019 hit Knives Out.

title: Shopping for Kitchen Stools
description: The stool has become an integral part of many kitchens  whether its pulled up at an island, a peninsula or a high cafe table.

title: Brooklyn Man Finds New Life in Crime (Writing)
description: It was over lunch in 2013 that the literary agent Eric Simonoff asked Jonathan Ames, So what do you want to do with your writing career?

title: The Supreme Courts Increasingly Dim View of the News Media
description: WASHINGTON  Last month, in a dissent in a routine libel case, a prominent federal judge lashed out at the news media.

title: Progressives Propose Tripling Housing Commitment in Infrastructure Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Top liberal lawmakers unveiled legislation on Monday that would pour more than $100 billion over a decade into modernizing the public housing system and starting a transition to renewable energy, as progressives seek to prod President Biden to expand his far-reaching infrastructure plan.

title: Fleeing a Modern War, Syrians Seek Refuge in Ancient Ruins
description: AL-KFEIR, Syria  As the sun set, children in dirty clothes and battered shoes herded sheep past the towering stone walls of a Byzantine settlement abandoned more than 1,000 years ago, leading them into an ancient cave nearby where the animals would spend the night.

title: Theres a Booming Business in Americas Forests. Some Arent Happy About It.
description: GARYSBURG, N.C.  In 2013, Kathy Claiborne got a noisy new neighbor. Thats when a huge factory that dries and presses wood into roughly cigarette-filter-sized pellets roared to life near her tidy home in one of the states poorest counties. On a recent afternoon in her front yard, near the end of a cul-de-sac, the mill rumbled like an uncomfortably close jet engine.

title: We Were Left With Nothing: Argentinas Misery Deepens in the Pandemic
description: Before the pandemic, Carla Huanca and her family were making modest but meaningful improvements to their cramped apartment in the slums of Buenos Aires.

title: Adults in all U.S. states are now eligible for vaccination, hitting Bidens target. Half have had at least one dose.
description: All adults in every U.S. state, Washington, D.C., and Puerto Rico are now eligible for a Covid-19 vaccine, meeting the April 19 deadline that President Biden set two weeks ago.

title: On the Water in Alaska, Where Salmon Fishing Dreams Live On
description: My camera lens is pressed against the window of the small floatplane as it flies below a thick ceiling of clouds. The mist clings to the hillsides of a temperate rainforest that descend steeply to the rocky coastline of southeast Alaska.

title: How the Johnson & Johnson Vaccine Pause Affects New York
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Theres a Name for the Blah Youre Feeling: Its Called Languishing
description: At first, I didnt recognize the symptoms that we all had in common. Friends mentioned that they were having trouble concentrating. Colleagues reported that even with vaccines on the horizon, they werent excited about 2021. A family member was staying up late to watch National Treasure again even though she knows the movie by heart. And instead of bouncing out of bed at 6 a.m., I was lying there until 7, playing Words with Friends.

title: How Much Do You Know About Ivory Coast?
description: Can you find Ivory Coast on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about 26 million people?

title: Wildfire Deals Hard Blow to South Africas Archives
description: JOHANNESBURG  Firefighters in Cape Town battled a wildfire on Monday that had engulfed the slopes of the citys famed Table Mountain and destroyed parts of the University of Cape Towns library, a devastating blow to the worlds archives of Southern African history.

title: New York spent $1.5 billion on its convention center. Will anyone come?
description: New York has just spent $1.5 billion to entice very large groups of people to gather under the same roof. When will that seem like a good idea again?

title: A Difficult Diplomatic Triangle
description: When a nuclear fuel enrichment site in Iran blew up this month, Tehran immediately said two things: The explosion was no accident, and the blame lay with Israel.

title: German Greens and Conservatives Choose Chancellor Candidates
description: BERLIN  Germanys top two parties announced their candidates for chancellor on Monday and early Tuesday morning, with the Greens sending their dynamic but inexperienced leader, Annalena Baerbock, 40, into the running against Armin Laschet, 60, the head of the largest conservative party, who triumphed after a divisive public power struggle.

title: Irrational Covid Fears
description: Guido Calabresi, a federal judge and Yale law professor, invented a little fable that he has been telling law students for more than three decades.

title: Aleksei Navalny Is Transferred to Hospital for Vitamin Treatment
description: MOSCOW  The Russian authorities moved the imprisoned opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to a hospital on Monday for what was described as treatment with vitamins.

title: Tottenham Hotspur Fires a Trophy-Less Jos Mourinho
description: Jos Mourinho was, in the eyes of the Tottenham Hotspur executives who hired him in 2019, the closest thing that soccer had to a guarantee of trophies.

title: Families are reunited as Australia and New Zealand begin their travel bubble.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Airports in Australia and New Zealand were filled with emotional scenes on Monday as thousands of passengers were allowed to travel freely between the two countries for the first time in more than a year.

title: How Corporate Donations Changed After the Capitol Riot
description: After the January 6 riot at the Capitol, scores of companies vowed to pause their political donations. Some stopped giving to all politicians, while others shunned only those 147 Republicans who voted to overturn the presidential election results. A recent deadline for candidates to release fund-raising details for the first quarter revealed more details about how corporate giving has changed.

title: India faces new lockdowns plus oxygen and drug shortages as cases spiral, and other news from around the world.
description: NEW DELHI  Delhi enacted a weeklong citywide lockdown on Monday, as infections and deaths in India hit new daily records and several local governments, including in the national capital, reported shortages of oxygen, beds and drugs.

title: U.N. Panel Is Scathing in Its Criticism of a British Report on Race
description: GENEVA  United Nations human rights experts on Monday issued a devastating critique of a report on race published last month by the British government, accusing its authors of repackaging racist tropes, distorting history and normalizing white supremacy.

title: Few Charges, Fewer Convictions: The Chauvin Trial and the History of Police Violence
description: A review of 19 deaths of Black Americans involving police officers shows that, despite public outrage, guilty verdicts are rare.

title: Biden, debating exit from Afghanistan, rejected generals views.
description: President Biden used his daily national security briefing on the morning of April 6 to deliver the news that his senior military leaders suspected was coming. He wanted all American troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11, the 20th anniversary of the attacks on New York and the Pentagon.

title: Heres how to watch the closing arguments in the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd is unusual for many reasons: It is being livestreamed from Minneapolis, attendance is severely limited because of the coronavirus and the publics interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.

title: Writing for the Chinese Diaspora
description: Good morning.

title: What You Get for $3 Million in California
description: A 1922 Wallace Neff house in Montecito, a Joseph Eichler midcentury home in Palo Alto and a 2005 Mediterranean townhouse in Huntington Beach.

title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: This house was designed by the architect Wallace Neff for John Willis Baer, the president of Occidental College from 1906 to 1916, and incorporates Spanish and Mediterranean elements. Original tiles throughout the house remain intact, as does an elevated platform in the living room designed to be occupied by musicians during large parties.

title: The Super League Announcement
description: Twelve leading European soccer clubs issued a statement on Sunday confirming their plans to form a breakaway league. Heres what they said at the time.

title: In effort to block variants, Hong Kong bans flights from three countries and empties an apartment block.
description: Hong Kong said it would ban flights from India, Pakistan and the Philippines for two weeks starting on Tuesday after detecting its first local case involving a variant of the coronavirus.

title: Watch Live: Day 16 of the Derek Chauvin Trial
description: Watch live video of closing arguments in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged in the death of George Floyd. Warning: The video may include graphic images.

title: Europes New Super League, Explained
description: A little more than a year after European soccer found a renewed sense of unity in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, the sport now faces its greatest crisis in a generation.

title: The Science of Climate Change Explained: Facts, Evidence and Proof
description: The science of climate change is more solid and widely agreed upon than you might think. But the scope of the topic, as well as rampant disinformation, can make it hard to separate fact from fiction. Here, weve done our best to present you with not only the most accurate scientific information, but also an explanation of how we know it.

title: The Pandemic Helped Me Realize How Essential My Routines Are
description: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times  what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.

title: Matthew McConaughey, governor of Texas? Voters seem all right with the idea, a poll found.
description: A new poll may put some wind in the actor Matthew McConaugheys sails as he considers whether to run for governor of Texas.

title: N.Y.P.D. to Limit Use of Sound Cannon on Crowds After Protesters Lawsuit
description: Police officers first deployed the earsplitting beeps against protesters more than a decade ago in Pittsburgh: Painfully loud noises emitted from a powerful speaker atop a police vehicle, a crowd-control device known informally as a sound cannon.

title: October Comes Early for Dodgers and Padres
description: SAN DIEGO  In April there is no red, white and blue bunting hanging anywhere quite yet, but you could have fooled San Diegos most enthusiastic baseball fans over the weekend. They streamed into the Gaslamp Quarter and Petco Park clothed in brown and mustard, limited only by their imaginations.

title: Harris visits North Carolina to promote Bidens infrastructure plan, saying it will create good jobs.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris traveled to North Carolina on Monday to promote the Biden administrations $20 billion proposal to convert the countrys entire fleet of gasoline- and diesel-powered school buses to electric vehicles, and to talk up the presidents plans to create good jobs.

title: What are the charges against Derek Chauvin?
description: The former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, 45, faces three charges in the death of George Floyd: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.

title: Night Crossings: Scenes From the U.S.-Mexico Border
description: ROMA, Texas  Shortly after sunset, there are signs of life on an isolated riverbank outside the border town of Roma, Texas. Over on the Mexican shore of the Rio Grande, flickering lights appear through the trees for a moment, then disappear.

title: New Week! New Recipes!
description: Good morning. Its a new week filled with new recipes and the joy of discovering older ones, and if I generally meet Mondays with a kind of empty sorrow  the weekend gone and still no newsroom into which to travel, another day at home at the same desk in the same empty room  this day, Im elated. There are fresh new fruits and vegetables in the shops, and my colleagues have delivered fresh new ideas for what to do with them!

title: Greece relaxes some quarantine rules as it prepares to welcome back tourists.
description: ATHENS  As part of a plan to revive its crucial tourism sector, Greece is lifting quarantine restrictions beginning Monday for arrivals from European Union member states and several other countries including the United States and Britain.

title: Vegetables Get the Ripert Treatment
description: Eric Riperts new collection of vegetable recipes is maybe one of the least seemingly chef-driven cookbooks. And it holds true to its title, Vegetable Simple. What a delightful approach, especially with summer on the horizon.

title: Flour Sack Towels With Flowery Appeal
description: The soft cotton that once went into making flour sacks is what the photographer Pauline Stevens has selected for her vibrant collection of kitchen towels decorated with her food-focused photographs.  Each is also printed with a literary quotation or a recipe for a dish, a drink or a sauce, most well-suited for Mothers Day giving. Theres a special set for the holiday. One of the towels, showing a bucket of roses, has a quote from E.M. Forster: I am sure that if mothers of various nations could meet, there would be no more wars. The other towel in the set also has roses, and a quote from Maya Angelou. Both measure 19-by-27 inches. Most of the towels are 27-inches square and come nicely packaged with a greeting card.

title: Analysis: Sectarianism is a growing threat to U.S. democracy, as camps increasingly see the other as an enemy.
description: American democracy faces many challenges: The corrosive effect of misinformation. The rise of domestic terrorism. Foreign interference in elections. New limits on voting rights. Efforts to subvert the peaceful transition of power. And making matters worse on all of these issues is a fundamental truth that the two political parties see the other as an enemy.

title: A Whimsical Chocolate Shop for the North Fork
description: Ursula Sala-Illa, who prefers to be known as Ursula XVII, has just opened her own chocolate shop, Atelier Disset, on the North Fork of Long Island. The pastry chefs complicated nomenclature has to do with her Catalonian roots. In the Catalan language disset means 17 (pronounce it and if you know French, youll also understand). Ursula XVII  a native New Yorker who worked at Ai Fiori in New York and with Albert Adri and Oriol Balaguer in Spain  has settled on the North Fork. On its website and in-store, the compact little shop sells finely crafted and decorated bonbon assortments with fillings like coconut marzipan and banana walnut, assorted bars and chunky cookies. Eventually she plans to hold workshops.

title: A Helper for Eastern Orthodox Easter
description: This year, Eastern Orthodox Easter comes on May 2. In a run-up to the celebration, there are some ingredients for traditional dishes that are worth having on hand, notably grape leaves, used for enclosing fillings to make dolmas (vine leaves stuffed with grains, meat or seafood) or to wrap fish before baking. The Greek food expert Diane Kochilas has recently added organic grape leaves from Crete to her website, along with recipes.

title: A New Source for Smoked Trout
description: With their eyes on Spain and Portugal (and the value given tinned seafood there), Caroline Goldfarb, a comedy television writer, and Becca Millstein, who worked in the entertainment industry, decided that better domestic canned choices were needed. Now theyre in the fish business as founders of Fishwife Tinned Seafood Co. Its latest release is Idaho rainbow trout lightly smoked over alder wood in Oregon and canned in sweet little toothpick-friendly chunks in olive oil, garlic, salt and brown sugar. A plate of it with green olives and a bottle of California albario, and youre good to go. Trout salad, trout tossed over pasta or added to a bowl of ramen are some other options. The trout joins their smoked domestic albacore tuna. The rainbow trout is sustainably farmed, and their albacore tuna is wild-caught.

title: Why the Knicks Keep, Ahem, Winning
description: It was only an overtime victory over the New Orleans Pelicans, the kind of win even pessimistic Knicks fans would have thought possible going into the season.

title: Will More Humanities Benefit Future Doctors?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Universal Eligibility, a Fifth of Seniors Remain Unvaccinated
description: Older adults have been eligible for Covid-19 vaccines for months, but some still have not gotten a shot, and progress is uneven from state to state.

title: Michael Musto, Lynn Yaeger and Mickey Boardman: Friends for Life
description: It was Manhattans print journalism scene that served as matchmaker to the Paper magazine editor at large Mickey Boardman, the writer Lynn Yaeger and the columnist Michael Musto, who have been friends for over 25 years and dedicated New Yorkers for even longer. In the early 90s, Yaeger, then the fashion editor at The Village Voice, assigned a story to Musto that never made it to press. My article was so appalling she didnt run it, but then we became friends, partly out of gossip and partly because we were on a lot of the same lists for parties, says Musto. He met Boardman in 1994, after receiving an invite to Papers 10th-anniversary bash. Michael and Bill Cunningham were, to me, the legendary documenters of downtown culture, says Boardman, who was subsequently introduced to Yaeger by Lauren Ezersky, the host of the television series Behind the Velvet Ropes, after she spotted the two aboard a long-since-retired Fashion Week bus that carried attendees from show to show. That bus is a good metaphor for what their friendship became: It was uptown, downtown, Midtown, everywhere, says Musto.

title: This Vegan Ramen Maximizes Flavor and Time
description: With most ramen, the work thats put into the broth is what makes all the difference, providing the foundation for the entire dish. A broth made with pork, chicken or seafood can be cooked for up to three days, resulting in an intense, velvety soup that sings with complex, multilayered flavors.

title: Times Event: We Need to Talk About Cancel Culture
description: Times subscribers can R.S.V.P. for this free event, Wednesday, May 12 at 7 p.m. Eastern.

title: Merrick Garland vows to combat domestic extremism as he commemorates the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.
description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said on Monday that the Justice Department was pouring resources into its effort to stop domestic violent extremists and that those who attacked the United States would be brought to justice, in a speech commemorating the 26th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Derek Chauvin Trial Judge Gives Instructions to Jury
description: With closing arguments beginning, Judge Peter A. Cahill read aloud the instructions to the jurors to follow in deciding their verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd.

title: A.C.L.U. Asks Supreme Court to Let It Seek Secret Surveillance Court Rulings
description: WASHINGTON  The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Supreme Court on Monday to unlock the doors to the nations foreign intelligence wiretapping court, arguing that Americans have a First Amendment right to ask its judges to disclose secret rulings affecting their privacy.

title: The Climate Clock Now Ticks With a Tinge of Optimism
description: A hint of optimism has been added to the Climate Clock, the set of decreasing numbers on the facade of a building in New Yorks Union Square that was conceived by two artists and activists, to communicate the urgency of curbing carbon emissions.

title: The Western Rides Again
description: A new cohort of directors, all women, is exploring the death wish that infuses the genreand proposing visions of repair.

title: Prosecutor in Derek Chauvin trial makes closing argument: This wasnt policing, this was murder.
description: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer and should be convicted of murder in George Floyds death.

title: Follow the Party Forever: China Plans a Communist Birthday Bash
description: Movie theaters in China are being ordered to screen patriotic films with titles like The Sacrifice and The Red Sun. Elementary students in some cities are being told to create paintings and calligraphy extolling the Chinese dream. Buses and subways are broadcasting nationalistic messages about revolutionary heroes.

title: Its a Theyby!
description: Is it possible to raise your child entirely without gender from birth? Some parents are trying.

title: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.
