description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Girl, Wash Your Timeline
description: May 14 was supposed to mark Rachel Holliss return to her happy place: a stage in front of an adoring audience.

title: Teaching About the Armenian Genocide With The New York Times
description: Featured Article: The Armenian Genocide, in History and Politics: What to Know

title: Catch up: Apple and Facebook profits doubled last quarter.
U.S. Economys Strong Start Signals a Stellar Year
description: Consumers shook off the pandemic blues as 2021 began, putting stimulus checks to work buying cars and other goods and helping set the stage for what could be the fastest economic growth in decades.

title: New state unemployment claims fall, a sign that the recovery is growing stronger.
description: Initial jobless claims fell last week to yet another pandemic low in the latest sign that the economic recovery is strengthening.

title: 100 U.S. colleges will require vaccinations to attend in-person classes in the fall.
description: More than 100 colleges across the United States have said they will require students to receive coronavirus vaccines in order to attend in-person classes in the fall, according to a New York Times survey.

title: Michio Kaku Says the Universe Is Simpler Than We Think
description: ORIGIN STORY The theoretical physicist Michio Kaku has built a parallel career as a best-selling writer on the future  of science, of the mind, of the human condition. Now, with The God Equation, No. 12 on the nonfiction list last week, Kaku turns his lens on the past.

title: Olivia Laings Reading Piles Are Far From Organized
description: There are something like 15,000 books in our house, says the author of Everybody and other books, including pretty much every poetry pamphlet published in the 20th century. Its a problem.

title: They Wanted a Blank Slate One-Bedroom for Less Than $1 Million. Which Option Would You Choose?
description: For their first purchase together, a young couple sought a place they could make their own  no cookie-cutter doorman buildings. Heres what they found.

title: Kicking Homer to the Curb: The American Scholar Who Upended the Classics
description: HEARING HOMERS SONGThe Brief Life and Big Idea of Milman ParryBy Robert Kanigel

title: Hate Will Not Define My Life
description: On a gray morning, just before the first lockdown, I bundled up and went on a brisk walk in Central Park. As my friend and I rounded a bend along the path where tourists ride horse-drawn carriages, a hipster-looking white guy breezed by on his skateboard. He looked me straight in the eye and, enunciating clearly, uttered one word  a racial slur so insidious it wont appear in this essay.

title: How Do You Illustrate Resilience? These Graphic Novels Show the Way.
description: A HOUSE WITHOUT WINDOWS (Humanoids, 166 pp., $19.99) pulls off something difficult with a quiet beauty. It mixes photography and comics from page to page, marshaling the strengths of each in the service of a devastating topic: the precarious lives of children in the Central African Republic, the former French colony that is one of the poorest countries in the world.

title: The Renaissances Most Influential Composer, 500 Years Later
description: For the 250th anniversary of Beethovens birth, the classical music field pulled out all the stops last year, even in the midst of pandemic performance cancellations around the world. But while 2021 brings its own significant anniversary  in August it will be 500 years since the death of Josquin des Prez, the most influential composer of his age  few listeners will know it.

title: The Wind and Solar Boom Is Here
description: Just one word, Benjamin: Solar.

title: Lets Stigmatize the Internet
description: It shouldnt have come as a surprise to anyone whos ever been on the internet that  during a pandemic, under several lockdowns  our worst online tendencies, in the immortal words of Spinal Tap, went to 11. It felt like everyone went slightly Jack Torrance from The Shining.

title: If You Dont Want to Go, Say No
description: When I was in my early 20s, my friends started calling me The Bailer. I was infamous for making plans and then canceling the day before. Even at the time, I knew this was irritating and ungenerous behavior. But I made the plans with the best intentions: I love my friends! I want to see their faces! That spoken-word event in a dank, low-ceilinged bar sounded like fun when you told me about it three weeks ago!

title: For $800, You Too Can Sort of Be In On This Joke
description: A few weeks ago, while browsing the internet, I came across a dark-blue rectangle for sale: Monochrome Bleu Numrique. I zoomed in, then out. I stared for long enough that I wondered whether it might have been a photograph of a photograph. A moment later it appeared to have a grainy texture, suggesting brush strokes on a canvas. But mostly it simply looked like a saturated, unnatural-seeming blue. This digital artwork, stored as a digital file, was for sale online when I first stumbled upon it for 0.3 Ether  the cryptocurrency for the blockchain platform Ethereum  worth more than $800, as of Tuesday night.

title: The Math That Explains the End of the Pandemic
description: The United States has vaccinated more than half of its adults against Covid-19, but it could be months until the country has vaccinated enough people to put herd immunity within reach (and much of the world is still desperately waiting for access to vaccines).

title: Let There Be Lunch!
description: In recent years, lunch has taken a punch. The power lunch of yore became the power breakfast, or among the intermittent fasting class, the power nothing whatsoever.

title: Mask Rules Are Relaxed. New Yorkers, Not So Much.
description: The morning after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that fully vaccinated Americans could hedonistically head outside, unmasked, under most circumstances, I left my apartment with a certain set of expectations.

title: 100 Days of Big, Bold, Partisan Change
description: I intended to duly fulfill my duty as a political columnist and write about the first 100 days of Joe Bidens presidency. My idea was to focus on the 50 Senate Democrats: They dont have a single vote to spare, they have to broker deals that satisfy both Bernie Sanders and Joe Manchin  America does have a multiparty political system, its just tucked inside the Senate Democratic caucus  and yet theyve held together pretty well, on a pretty ambitious agenda.

title: They Survived Covid. Now They Need New Lungs.
description: BOSTON  He survived Covid-19, but his lungs were ravaged. After months of deep sedation, he is delirious, his muscles atrophied. And this 61-year-old still cannot breathe on his own.

title: Why Is Perimenopause Still Such a Mystery?
description: Angie McKaig calls it peri brain out loud, in meetings. Thats when the 49-year-old has moments of perimenopause-related brain fog so intense that she will forget the point she is trying to make in the middle of a sentence. Sometimes it will happen when shes presenting to her colleagues in digital marketing at Canadas largest bank in Toronto. But it can happen anywhere  she has forgotten her own address. Twice.

title: 10 Self-Help Essays to Read Before Re-entering Society
The Case for a National One-Week Vacation
A Progressive Vision Is Possible if We Spend Money Thoughtfully Now
description: Last night, President Biden offered a vision of government as an instrument for progress not heard from a president since Lyndon Johnson. Congress should put that vision into legislation this summer, but success will also depend on countless smaller decisions made across the country.

title: Disneyland is Reopening. Heres What You Need to Know.
description: After being closed for more than a year, Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., reopened on Friday to residents of the state only. Travel advisers around the country said tickets and reservations sold out quickly, and people have been waiting online for hours to get a reservation.

title: He Fought for Decades to Make Marijuana Legal. Now What?
description: Dana Beal stood in Union Square Park explaining the provenance of the pot being given away to a crowd of expectant people who were gathering near a bronze statue of George Washington astride a horse.

title: Vaccine Skepticism Was Viewed as a Knowledge Problem. Its Actually About Gut Beliefs.
description: For years, scientists and doctors have treated vaccine skepticism as a knowledge problem. If patients were hesitant to get vaccinated, the thinking went, they simply needed more information.

title: Crossing the Niger River, Inch by Painful Inch, Hour by Wasted Hour
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Spring jazz programming is in full swing again  most of it still virtual, but some of it in person. The big event on Friday is International Jazz Day, an annual UNESCO-sponsored celebration now in its 10th year, which culminates in the All-Star Global Concert, streaming at jazzday.com at 5 p.m. Eastern time, with artists including Herbie Hancock, Melissa Aldana and Anglique Kidjo beaming in from across the world. (PBS stations will air a special documentary on International Jazz Day at 8 p.m.)

title: Why Is So Much Money Moving to Miami?
description: Big names in tech including Peter Thiel and Keith Rabois have moved to Miami in the past year. Mayor Francis Suarez is welcoming them with open arms in his zeal to transform Miami into the next tech hub. The sell? Sunshine, low taxes and a mayor who is always willing to take their calls (or, as Kara Swisher puts it, pet them.)

title: 10 Classical Concerts to Stream in May
description: With in-person performances not yet quite widespread, here are 10 highlights from the flood of online music content coming in May. (Times listed are Eastern.)

title: Biden Has Elevated the Job of Science Adviser. Is That What Science Needs?
description: On the campaign trail, Joseph R. Biden Jr. vowed to unseat Donald J. Trump and bring science back to the White House, the federal government and the nation after years of presidential attacks and disavowals, neglect and disarray.

title: Why This N.Y.P.D. Detective Is Suing a Protester
description: When demonstrations against racism and brutality in policing filled New Yorks streets last summer, the police confronted protesters with tactics so aggressive and at times violent that a remorseful Mayor Bill de Blasio later issued a public apology.

title: How Will Camps Keep Kids Safe This Summer?
description: At 8:30 one morning in March, online registration opened for the summer day camp run by my local community center. By 8:35 a.m., all the spots were taken and a wait list was building.

title: Teslas Latest Solar Stumble: Big Price Increases
description: On an October evening five years ago, Elon Musk used a former set for Desperate Housewives to show off Teslas latest innovation: roof shingles that can generate electricity from the sun without unsightly solar panels.

title: Diapers, Cereal and, Yes, Toilet Paper Are Going to Get More Expensive
description: Procter & Gamble is raising prices on items like Pampers and Tampax in September. Kimberly-Clark said in March that it will raise prices on Scott toilet paper, Huggies and Pull-Ups in June, a move that is necessary to help offset significant commodity cost inflation.

title: They Call It Social Cleansing: Court May Force Honduras to Better Protect Trans People
description: In a region where experts put the life expectancy for transgender women at only 30 to 35 years, Vicky Hernndez didnt make it even that long.

title: Dog Biting Dog: Chinas Online Fight Could Further Empower Beijing
description: Hours after the Chinese government imposed a record $2.8 billion fine on Alibaba, a veteran internet entrepreneur urged regulators to do something similar to his companys biggest competitor.

title: After Thoughts
description: Returning to public life happier in their trans body.

title: At 100 Days, Biden Is Transforming What It Means to Be a Democrat
description: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. served as vice president in the Obama administration, he was known to preface his recommendations to other officials with a self-deprecating disclaimer. He may not have attended Harvard or Yale, Mr. Biden would say as he popped into an office or a meeting, but he was still a foreign policy expert, and he knew how to work Capitol Hill.

title: We Know Where the Sheikhs Horse Is. But Where Is His Daughter?
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  For nearly 40 years, Dubais ruler has spent vast sums here in central Kentucky. On thousands of acres of lush bluegrass with gently rolling hills mapped by limestone and plank fences. On horses  stallions and mares to populate his farms with foals and yearlings purchased in the sales ring.

title: Joy, Love, Grief: How It Looks When Families Reunite
description: A daughter holding her mothers hand. A son overcome that his 95-year-old mother survived the pandemic. A stoic family patriarch, suddenly in tears.

title: How to Recognize and Treat Perimenopause and Menopause Symptoms
description: Many women dont know what to expect during perimenopause, which is the time period  often marked by distressing changes in the body  that leads up to menopause, or the end of a womans menstrual cycle and childbearing years. Those changes can come as a shock, so we broke down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.

title: A Candidate for N.Y.C. Mayor Is Accused of Sexual Assault
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Airbus returns to profit but warns crisis is not over.
description: Airbus announced Thursday that it had returned to a profit in the first quarter following a 1.1 billion euro loss last year because of the coronavirus pandemic, but its top executive warned that the economic toll would continue.

title: We Have to Prove Democracy Still Works
description: Yesterday, President Biden gave his first address to a joint session of Congress.

title: New David Hockney Billboards to Brighten 5 Cities in May
description: Two suns will appear in five cities during the month of May  the real sun in the sky, of course, but also the chrysanthemum-like depiction of it in a video by the British artist David Hockney. The 2-minute animation will be broadcast on digital billboards in Times Square in New York and prominent locations in London, Los Angeles, Tokyo and Seoul.

title: New York Times photographers capture families reuniting at nursing homes.
description: A daughter holding her mothers hand. A son overcome that his 95-year-old mother had survived the pandemic. A stoic family patriarch, suddenly in tears.

title: Biden and the Vaccination Slowdown
description: President Biden used the beginning of his speech to Congress last night to celebrate the speed of the countrys vaccination program. And he deserves a lot of credit for it.

title: Navalnys Network Crumbling Under Kremlin Pressure
description: MOSCOW  Associates of Aleksei A. Navalny said they were shutting down their nationwide network of regional offices on Thursday even as the imprisoned Russian opposition leader vowed, in an online court appearance, to keep fighting the emperor with no clothes in the Kremlin.

title: The Departed Could Soon Become Compost in Colorado
description: DENVER  Food scraps and biodegradable utensils are common fodder for compost, but in Colorado, human remains could soon be transformed into soil too.

title: Limbo Review: A Musician in Exile Tunes Out
description: Most of the films weve seen about the migrant and refugee situation in Europe in recent years are gritty, often heartbreaking dramas and documentaries. Limbo, written and directed by a ferociously talented filmmaker, Ben Sharrock, takes an insinuating, poetic and often wryly funny approach. And its both heartbreaking and heartlifting.

title: Lucy, the Human Chimp Review: Far From Home
description: Theres a strange irony in the appalling trajectory of Lucy the Human Chimp, a documentary about an experiment that forced a chimp to live as a human, but resulted in requiring a human to live as a chimp.

title: Percy vs Goliath Review: Growing Pains
description: Percy vs Goliath might be based on a 1998 Canadian legal battle and its fallout, but Clark Johnsons ambling, warmhearted movie doesnt lean on courtroom tension for drama. Addressing high stakes  the degree to which agribusiness controls our food supply  in an extremely low key, Johnson uses one familys plight to illustrate the predicament of an entire industry.

title: The Outside Story Review: Brooklyn as No One Has Ever Known It
description: The comedy The Outside Story takes a listless look at the life of Charles (Brian Tyree Henry), who is moping over his breakup with his unfaithful girlfriend, Isha (Sonequa Martin-Green). When Charles chases down a delivery person to offer a belated tip, he gets locked out of his Brooklyn apartment for a day and must set his self-pity aside.

title: Four Good Days Review: Repairing a Mother-Daughter Relationship
description: Four Good Days deals with the recoveries of two people: a heroin addict and her mother, who has given up on trusting her daughter.

title: Berlin Alexanderplatz Review: Reframing an Urban Classic
description: Alfred Dblins masterpiece Berlin Alexanderplatz received its most famous dramatization not at the movies but on TV, with Rainer Werner Fassbinders 15-hour adaptation in 1980. Burhan Qurbanis ambitious film by the same name re-centers the Weimar Era original on a 21st-century immigrant from Guinea-Bissau who seeks the straight and narrow but works for a psychopathic drug dealer.

title: Tom Clancys Without Remorse Review: A Routine Mission
description: Situating the bulk of its action in 2019, Tom Clancys Without Remorse updates Clancys 1993 novel by opening with a prologue in Aleppo, Syria, and making reference to the Russian military presence in the country. But the geopolitics and relative lack of cyber-anything otherwise date the movie to a barely post-Cold War period, while the plot mechanics grind along like holdovers from Charles Bronsons heyday.

title: Cliff Walkers Review: Double Crosses and Double Agents
description: Cliff Walkers, the new picture from the protean Chinese director Zhang Yimou, arrives here after a hiccup in his filmography.

title: Eat Wheaties! Review: Chasing Ms. Banks
description: With his debut film, Eat Wheaties!, Scott Abramovitch has wrangled the kind of cast that most first-time directors dream of: a whos-who of TV comedy that includes Tony Hale (Arrested Development, Veep), Elisha Cuthbert, Lamorne Morris, Sarah Chalke and Alan Tudyk. But what Abramovitch does with such a lineup is an unfortunate, unfunny mess.

title: About Endlessness Review: Heaven Knows Im Miserable Now
description: In his elegy for William Butler Yeats, W.H. Auden instructed poets to sing of human unsuccess/in a rapture of distress. The Swedish filmmaker Roy Andersson may be the great cinematic bard of failure and futility, though his version of rapture is a decidedly low-key affair. About Endlessness, his new feature, is at once gloomy and vivid, 76 minutes worth of vignettes that are individually somber and cumulatively exhilarating.

title: The Virtuoso Review: A Paid Killer, Hitting Bum Notes
description: The existential anxiety of the paid assassin is a tricky theme  so tricky as to be potentially invalid, even. The Virtuoso, directed by Nick Stagliano from a script by James C. Wolf, misses its shot in a spectacular, and sometimes spectacularly pretentious, fashion.

title: Things Heard & Seen Review: Another Real Estate Nightmare
description: Ill say this much for Things Heard & Seen: it absolutely lives up to its name. If, out of curiosity or inertia, you let your Netflix algorithm have its way for two hours, you will definitely hear and see some things, though you may have trouble afterward remembering just what those things were.

title: Hong Kong eases some restrictions to encourage vaccinations, and other news from around the world.
description: Hong Kong eased restrictions on Thursday at restaurants and bars where staff and customers have begun receiving coronavirus vaccinations, part of an effort to help businesses hurt by the pandemic while attempting to boost an anemic inoculation drive.

title: How Long Will These Children Live?
description: Tremendous gains on life expectancy have been made around the world, but huge gaps remain. We photographed scenes from the global fight for a more equal life span.

title: What Grade Would You Give President Biden on His First 100 Days?
description: When President Biden took office in January, we asked students what the new administrations priorities should be. We heard from teenagers who wanted Mr. Biden to distribute coronavirus vaccines, support veterans, address police brutality, curb climate change and prioritize unity and bipartisanship.

title: This Angry Bird Is the Most Photogenic, Research Finds
description: With its broad, hooked beak and wide eyes, the frogmouth  a nocturnal bird that is sometimes mistaken for an owl  is a striking sight.

title: Cows and Cellos
The Lesson of Tony Blairs Long Hair
description: What is it with male politicians and their hair these days? After decades  centuries  of nondescript short cuts, their crowning glory has suddenly turned into a form of creative expression. And source of controversy.

title: Bidens Big Speech, by the Numbers
description: Today is President Bidens 100th day in office, and yesterday he delivered his first address to a joint session of Congress. In his speech, he laid out an agenda that, The Timess Peter Baker writes, represents a fundamental reorientation of the role of government not seen since the days of Lyndon B. Johnsons Great Society and Roosevelts New Deal. The centerpiece of his address was a plan for some $4 trillion in spending, split into two bills, on top of the $1.9 billion in economic aid already passed earlier in his term.

title: Profits surge at Shell and Total, reflecting higher oil and gas prices.
description: Strong profit increases from two of Europes largest energy companies, Royal Dutch Shell and Total, demonstrated that what really matters for the financial performance of these companies remains the price of oil and natural gas.

title: In a Dark Time, This Music Will Make You Smile
description: Last fall, when the world was being told to expect a long, dark winter after what had already been a brutal year, I decided to search for some new, bracing orchestral music. It had been months since Id been walloped by symphonic forces in a live setting. And if it was to be grim times ahead, I wanted at least some music that gestured toward that sense of scale.

title: What to Expect in the First Round of the N.F.L. Draft
description: Soon it will all be over  the guesses, the hunches, the smoke screens, the informed speculation, the uninformed speculation and, especially, the billions of mock drafts, which have elicited untold page views and paroxysms of internet rage but that as of around 8:15 p.m. Eastern time Thursday will be as relevant as the mock drafts released Friday for 2022.

title: President Biden Gives a Pep Talk for Still-Unusual Times
description: This gathering is just a little bit different, President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Wednesday night, opening his first address to a joint session of Congress.

title: Comcast Earnings Spotlight the Media Industrys Upheaval
description: If you want a clear picture of the state of the media industry in upheaval, Comcast offers a good snapshot.

title: Biden is transforming what it means to be a Democrat.
description: Now 100 days into his presidency, President Biden is driving the biggest expansion of American government in decades, an effort to use $6 trillion in federal spending to address social and economic challenges at a scale not seen in a half-century. Aides say he has come into his own as a party leader in ways that his uneven political career didnt always foretell, and that he is undeterred by matters that used to bother him, like having no Republican support for Democratic priorities.

title: Sothebys and Phillips Announce Departures and Arrivals
description: On Wednesday, two of the three major auction houses announced shifts in the makeup of their leadership teams.

title: Whats Going On in This Graph? | May 5, 2021
Heres How to Claim Your Stimulus Payments: File Your Tax Return
description: Good morning.

title: Microsoft plans to take a smaller cut from developers in its games store.
description: Microsoft will decrease the share of money it charges independent developers that publish PC games on its online store, starting in August, the company said on Thursday.

title: The Mitchells vs. the Machines Review: When Bots Attack
description: Nothing says family bonding like a road trip through a robot apocalypse. At least thats the case for the Mitchells in the quirky and riotously funny Netflix animated film The Mitchells vs. the Machines.

title: Do I Really Need to State My Pronouns?
description: My firm asked all employees to add our pronouns to our email signatures to promote inclusivity. So, I did: He/him/his. I am in sales and send out hundreds of outreach emails every week. Today, a potential customer replied: Not interested. He said he was turned off by the unnecessary pronoun thing. I support inclusivity. But this interaction made me wonder about the risks and rewards of my companys policy. My email signature isnt suddenly going to make anyone more welcoming to nonbinary people. But some may be turned off by it. And I dont think leaving off my pronouns would offend anyone. Am I wrong?

title: The Senate begins considering a diverse slate of Bidens judicial nominees.
description: Democrats have begun advancing President Bidens first judicial nominees through the Senate Judiciary Committee, taking a significant step to counter the influence President Donald J. Trump had in steering the federal courts to the right.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: She Bought a Truck on eBay, Then Forgot It. A Dementia Diagnosis Came Later.
description: After Maria Turners minivan was totaled in an accident a dozen years ago, she grew impatient waiting for the insurance company to process the claim.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are a four-bedroom house in Skillman, N.J., and a six-bedroom house in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Park Slope, the East Village and on the Upper East Side.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Pope Francis Issues Law to Combat Corruption in the Vatican
description: ROME  In an effort to fight corruption in the highest ranks of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis issued a sweeping new decree on Thursday compelling top managers at the Vatican  including cardinals  to provide full financial disclosures and to refuse any gifts worth more than roughly $50.

title: The S.E.C. delays a long-awaited decision on whether to allow a Bitcoin fund.
description: For many cryptocurrency supporters and investors, regulatory approval of a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund in the United States represents the holy grail. It would allow the crypto-curious to get exposure to Bitcoin without having to buy the tokens themselves, signifying that digital assets are really, truly mainstream.

title: Patti Harrison Wants to See What She Can Do
description: Patti Harrison, the actress and comedian, has taken one acting class in her life, an introductory course at Ohio University. It was taught by a grad student and was very loose, she said. We mostly just did yoga.

title: When Are the Olympics? Heres the Schedule for Tokyo.
description: The Tokyo Olympics, delayed for a year because of the coronavirus pandemic, are now scheduled for late July and early August. The time difference between Japan and the United States may make it tricky to figure out what will happen when, but were here to help.

title: France sets a timeline to emerge from a third lockdown, and other news from around the world.
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France outlined plans on Thursday for the gradual reopening of the country, plotting a path out of the labyrinth of restrictions in place and fueling hope that life might finally return to normal after waves of infections forced the country into three national lockdowns.

title: What drove the first-quarter economy: spending on goods.
description: The first-quarter economic recovery, when the economy expanded 1.6 percent, was powered by spending. Specifically, by spending on stuff.

title: German High Court Hands Youth a Victory in Climate Change Fight
description: BERLIN  Germanys highest court ordered the government to expand a 2019 law aimed at bringing the countrys carbon emissions down to nearly zero by 2050, ruling on Thursday that the legislation did not go far enough to ensure that future generations would be protected.

title: The Economy Is (Almost) Back. It Is Looking Different Than It Used To.
description: There have been a lot of strange economic numbers over the last 14 months, as the world has been whipsawed by the pandemic. But one particular line of the first-quarter G.D.P. numbers released Thursday stands out even so.

title: Marighella Review: Battle for Brazil
description: In 2018, the Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro declared that he wanted a Brazil similar to the one we had 40, 50 years ago referring to the era of the countrys military dictatorship, which saw violent censorship and the torture of dissidents.

title: E.U. Says Americans Can Come, but Europeans Wonder How
description: On March 31, President Emmanuel Macron of France announced the start of a third national lockdown in a bid to control the spread of a new deadly wave of the coronavirus. Domestic travel between regions is forbidden and restaurants, bars and cafes remain closed.

title: Do I Have to Get the Covid Vaccine in My Arm?
description: By now most people are familiar with how the Covid-19 vaccine is typically administered: a quick jab to the upper arm. But there is a lesser known place on the body where the vaccine has also been approved for injection: the thigh.

title: Biden Calls for U.S. to Enter a New Superpower Struggle
description: President Biden has justified his broad vision to remake the American economy as the necessary step to survive long-run competition with China, a foot race in which the United States must prove not only that democracies can deliver, but that it can continue to out-innovate and outproduce the worlds most successful authoritarian state.

title: The World Knows Her as Disaster Girl. She Just Made $500,000 Off the Meme.
description: The name Zo Roth might not ring any bells. But chances are youve seen her photo.

title: McDonalds says sales are back to prepandemic levels.
description: McDonalds said Thursday that sales of Big Macs, chicken nuggets and french fries got back to prepandemic levels in the first part of the year.

title: Mask On or Off? Life Is Getting Back to Normal, and Were Rusty.
description: Mark Rasch hopped on his bike Tuesday in Bethesda, Md., pedaled off for an afternoon ride, and realized he forgot his mask. As he turned back for it, news came on the radio over his earbuds: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said masks were no longer required outdoors for fully vaccinated people unless they were in a crowd.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: There are woods near my house where I sometimes head when Im craving green shadows and stillness, a reminder that time and nature have very little to do with the human scale of things. Very little  but not nothing: As Scott Weidensaul points out in his new book about migratory birds, A World on the Wing, humans are deeply implicated in the recent decimation of aviation species. If you love the woods as I do, this book will make you more alert to the chirrups and whistles and flashes of movement in the canopy above you and give you new respect for birds incredible abilities. Its one of our recommended titles this week.

title: Joe Biden Has the Vision. Now Chuck Schumer Has to Bring It to Life.
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden laid out his ambitious vision for a post-pandemic America on Wednesday night. Now it is up to Senator Chuck Schumer to make it a reality.

title: Whats in Our Queue? Survivor and More
description: Im a reporter for the Culture Desk with a focus on music. Here are five ways I've been entertaining myself lately.

title: Senators announce proposed law removing commanders from military sexual assault cases.
description: For nearly a decade, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, has tried to pass legislation that would remove military commanders from their role in prosecuting service members for sexual assault.

title: Dont Ignore Ransomware. Its Bad.
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Rajan Mishra, Classical Indian Vocalist, Dies at 69
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Food Is Not a Prop for Senator Jessica Ramos. Its a Platform.
description: Last spring, when long lines at food pantries first began to form in Queens  where the coronavirus struck harder than almost anywhere else in the country  Jessica Ramos, a New York state senator, knew whom to call to feed her neighbors.

title: How to Clean White Sneakers
description: Heres how to get your well-worn shoes looking their best.

title: No, Other Peoples Covid Vaccines Cant Disrupt Your Menstrual Cycle
description: In recent weeks, people who oppose Covid vaccinations have spread a claim that is not only false but defies the rules of biology: that being near someone who has received a vaccine can disrupt a womans menstrual cycle or cause a miscarriage.

title: Review: A New Mosquito Coast, This Time With Narcos
description: The television series called The Mosquito Coast that premieres Friday on Apple TV+ has so little in common with the best-selling 1981 novel of that name that comparison doesnt get you far. This is true even though the novelist, Paul Theroux, is an executive producer of the show and his nephew Justin Theroux is the star.

title: A Photographer Looks Deep Into Americas Past
description: Before he became a photographer, Dawoud Bey trained as a jazz percussionist, looking to John Coltrane as a role model for melding craft with a commitment to social justice. As a teenager in the 1960s, Bey was finely attuned to the social and political upheavals of the civil rights movement, staging sit-ins and demonstrations with his high school classmates and joining the Black Panther Party, whose newspaper he sold on the weekends. By 1968, the struggle for racial equality was converging with demonstrations against the war in Vietnam and the early stages of womens liberation, forming a pattern of transformation and upheaval that culminated with the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Facing Droughts, California Challenges Nestl Over Water Use
description: After another dry winter that threatens to worsen water shortages across California, state officials have accused a water bottling company of diverting too much water from forests in the San Bernardino area.

title: Fat Ham Review: A Queer, Black Hamlet? Ay, Theres the Spice Rub.
description: Perhaps the real tragedy of Hamlet is that it doesnt end with a dance party; too many of its characters lie dead at the final curtain for anyone to shake a leg.

title: Good Luck to Republicans if Bidens Family Plan Becomes Law
description: Conservatives beware: If the main elements in Joe Bidens American Family Plan become law, theyll be very hard to repeal. Why? Because theyll deliver huge, indeed transformational benefits to millions.

title: A Sharp Divide at the Supreme Court Over a One-Letter Word
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the government must comply strictly with a requirement that immigrants receive detailed notices about their deportation hearings.

title: No Need to Take Risks to Prove Friendship
description: To the Editor:

title: Bidens Ambitious Agenda for America
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan warns of new strictures as its daily Covid death toll sets a record.
description: With Covid-19 deaths surging to records in Pakistan this week, the government has sent troops to the streets to help enforce coronavirus precautions, and is warning it may turn to a lockdown if the spread is not controlled.

title: 5 People, Including 2 Deputies, Are Killed in North Carolina Standoff
description: Two sheriffs deputies were among four people who were killed in a 13-hour standoff in Boone, N.C., that the authorities said started on Wednesday morning when they were called to the home of a man who had not shown up for work.

title: Biden says he was not told the F.B.I. planned to search Giulianis office and home.
description: President Biden said on Thursday that he was not told in advance about the F.B.I.s execution of search warrants at Rudolph W. Giulianis office and home, citing his pledge not to meddle in law enforcement matters.

title: Turkey braces for its strictest lockdown yet, as the virus surges and vaccinations lag.
description: The streets of Istanbul were abuzz, the grocery stores packed, the seaside promenades crowded but it was not the bustle of an ordinary spring Thursday. People were flocking to take advantage of the last day before a new lockdown takes hold, the strictest in Turkey since the pandemic began.

title: Cuomo Loses Another Key Aide as Vaccine Czar Steps Down
description: Larry Schwartz, one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos most trusted advisers, unexpectedly stepped down from his role as New York States vaccine czar, about five months after he was recruited by the governor to spearhead the states vaccine rollout.

title: The Traveling Zoo: Life on the Road, With Pets at Their Side
description: It can get lonely on the road, but Rebecca Washington, a long-distance trucker who is sometimes away from home for months on end, has Ziggy, Polly, Junior and Tucker along for the ride: her rig dogs.

title: How to Breathe New Life Into Martha Grahams Dances? Infuse Them With Art.
description: If the pandemic has taught Janet Eilber anything, its this: Im always reminded how potent Marthas work is, she said, when we mess with it.

title: Telemedicine Is a Tool. Not a Replacement for Your Doctors Touch.
description: Earlier in the pandemic it was vital to see doctors over platforms like Zoom or FaceTime when in-person appointments posed risks of coronavirus exposure. Insurers were forced  often for the first time  to reimburse for all sorts of virtual medical visits and generally at the same price as in-person consultations.

title: Only 8 Black Students Are Admitted to Stuyvesant High School
description: After a year in which the pandemic shined a harsh spotlight on the stark inequities in New York Citys school system, the city announced Thursday that, once again, only tiny numbers of Black and Latino students had been admitted into top public high schools. The numbers represent the latest signal that efforts to desegregate those schools while maintaining an admissions exam are failing.

title: The Vanished Glamour of Midcentury Print Media
description: In a city whose news kiosks have become glorified chewing gum emporiums, where the Grand Central newsstand shelves are overtaken by chips and phone chargers, one of my few remaining happy places is Casa Magazines. Its a hole of a shop on the corner of Eighth Avenue and 12th Street, and every wall and every inch of floor heaves with obscure, international fashion and design publications, for a dwindling class of print lovers. (I still remember, when I founded a magazine in 2015, the relief I felt when I saw my first issue piled on the floor of Casa; then it was real.) Once upon a time, before New York was swallowed into the smartphone screen, the city had dozens of shops like this. Now, if you care about fashion photography and print design, you probably belong in a museum.

title: Be It a $10 Wine, or Much More, the Judgments Come Free
description: Of all the undying clichs about wine, perhaps the one I hear most often is, Theres no correlation between price and quality.

title: Txakolina for Good Cheer, Wherever You May Be
description: Ive been craving outdoor time with friends whom I barely saw through the long pandemic winter. Here in New York City, I think weve finally seen the last of the cold.

title: Does It Matter if I Skip My Second Covid Shot?
description: Millions of people have missed their second dose of Covid-19 vaccine. But does it really matter?

title: Cathy Park Hong
description: Who is us? What is us? Is there even such a concept as an Asian-American consciousness? The writer Cathy Park Hong searches for answers to these questions in her book of essays, Minor Feelings: An Asian American Reckoning. Hongs book, which came out in February 2020, has taken on new urgency with the rise in anti-Asian violence and discrimination during the pandemic. Today, Hong joins Jenna and Wesley to discuss the usefulness of rage, and her experience of speaking for  and listening to  the Asian-American community.

title: Twitters revenue jumps 28 percent in its first post-Trump quarter.
description: Twitter said on Thursday that its revenue in the first quarter of the year was $1.04 billion, a 28 percent increase from the same quarter the previous year that modestly exceeded analyst expectations. Net income for the quarter was $68 million, a turnaround from an $8.4 million loss in the same quarter a year ago.

title: Central Asian Border Dispute Casts Shadow Over U.S. Afghan Departure
description: MOSCOW  Fighting broke out on Thursday between Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan over control of an irrigation canal and an access road to an ethnic enclave, raising the specter of instability in Central Asia as the United States prepares to withdraw from Afghanistan.

title: The C.D.C. eases rules for cruises, making mid-July trips possible.
description: Cruise ships that have been docked for more than a year could restart sailing in United States waters by mid-July, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a letter sent to the cruise industry late on Wednesday.

title: Biden Is Giving Child Care Prime-Time Attention. Can He Actually Transform It?
description: Senator Patty Murray of Washington

title: F.D.A. Announces Plan to Ban Menthol Cigarettes and Flavored Cigars
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced its long-awaited plan to ban the last flavor still allowed in cigarettes  menthol  and also said it would ban all flavors of mass-produced cigars, which are popular among youths. The ban would apply only to sales, manufacturing and imports  not personal possession.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: Amazons profit soars 220 percent as pandemic drives shopping online.
description: With the pandemic shifting sales online and consumers flush with stimulus checks, Amazon on Thursday reported $108.5 billion in sales in the first three months of the year, up 44 percent from a year earlier. It also posted $8.1 billion in profit, an increase of 220 percent from the same period last year.

title: After a Year of Loss, South America Suffers Worst Death Tolls Yet
description: BOGOT, Colombia  In the capital of Colombia, Bogot, the mayor is warning residents to brace for the worst two weeks of our lives.

title: What Is Cheugy? You Know It When You See It.
description: OK TikTok, I have a new word for you that my friends and I use that you clearly are all in need of, Hallie Cain, 24, a copywriter in Los Angeles says in a TikTok posted on March 30.

title: Overlooked No More: Inji Efflatoun, Egyptian Artist of the People
description: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

title: Sleep to Clean: A Prevention of Plaques That Lead to Alzheimers Disease
description: This essay, by Jocelyn Tan, age 15, from Ridge High School, Basking Ridge, N.J., is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: The Motion of the Ocean: Using Sea Waves to Desalinate Seawater
description: This essay, by Dana Steinke, age 16, from Saratoga High School, Saratoga, Calif., is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Auto sales helped get the American economy off to a good start in 2021.
description: In the first months of 2021, what was good for the auto industry was decidedly good for the American economy.

title: From Babbling to Birdsong: What Finches Can Teach Us About Vocal Learning
description: This essay, by Kelly Shen, age 16, from Sacred Heart Schools, Atherton in Atherton, Calif., is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: The Worlds Best Quarantiners
description: This essay, by Erin Rasmussen, age 14, from Andover High School in Andover, Mass., is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: And the Grammy Goes to  Fin Whales?
description: This essay, by Nicola Myers, age 17, from Boise High School in Boise, Idaho, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: In the first three months of 2021, the U.S. shook off some of the lingering effects of the pandemic on its economy. Consumer spending grew 2.6 percent and the first-quarter growth rate reached 6.4 percent. Economists predict overall economic activity could return to prepandemic levels in the current quarter.

title: The Peacock Mantis Shrimp: The Ant-Man of Atlantis
description: This essay, by Suleiman Mohamed, age 16, from British School Muscat in Muscat, Oman, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Origami in Space Engineering: Rediscovering the Meaning of Discovery
description: This essay, by Hoonsun Lee, age 17, from Cornerstone Collegiate Academy of Seoul in Seoul, South Korea, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: A Rising Star: These Star-Shaped Polymers May Be Our Last Defense Against Superbugs
description: This essay, by Jaejeong Kim, age, 17, from Hunter College High School in New York City, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Dishwashers and Dementia: The Brain System Youve Never Heard Of
description: This essay, by Maggie Bell, age 16, from Lakeside High School in Atlanta, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Unleash the Tests: The Four-Legged Future of Covid-19 Testing
description: This essay, by Sophie Araten, age 15, from Millburn High School in Millburn, N.J., is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: Mycowood Violins: A Different Kind of Time Machine
description: This essay, by Natalia Araa, 16, from Philippine Science High School in Quezon City, Philippines, is one of the top 11 winners of The Learning Networks second annual STEM Writing Contest, for which we received 3,741 entries. You can find the work of all of our student winners here.

title: A 22-Million-Year Journey From the Asteroid Belt to Botswana
description: On the morning of June 2, 2018, an asteroid was seen careening toward us at 38,000 miles per hour. It was going to impact Earth, and there was nothing anyone could do to stop it. Astronomers were beside themselves with excitement.

title: Anthony Powell, Oscar-Winning Costume Designer, Dies at 85
description: Anthony Powell, an inventive British costume designer who won three Oscars but is perhaps best known for the outlandish clothing he conceived for Glenn Close as the fur-loving Cruella de Vil in 101 Dalmatians and its sequel, died on April 16 in London. He was 85.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The new mask guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which says that vaccinated people can go barefaced in most outdoor settings, is a baby step back to normalcy. But after the trauma of the past year, many Americans are finding it difficult to uncover their faces so quickly  let alone return to their old ways.

title: Star Polymers, Space Origami and Singing Finches: The Winners of Our 2nd Annual STEM Writing Contest
description: Where do scientists  and science writers  get their ideas? They pay close attention to the world around them and ask questions, then look for answers to the ones that fascinate them most.

title: What Students Are Saying About Learning Loss During the Pandemic
description: In the article Does It Hurt Children to Measure Pandemic Learning Loss?, Dana Goldstein explores the debate among educators about how to measure learning gaps experienced during the pandemic  if we should measure them at all, that is.

title: Sacrifice Fly Pushes Orioles Past Yankees in Extra Innings
description: Cedric Mullins delivered a winning sacrifice fly in the 10th inning, Trey Mancini had his first three-hit game since returning from colon cancer surgery, and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Yankees, 4-3, Thursday for a four-game series split.

title: U.S. Economy, Menthol Cigarettes, N.F.L.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Perfect Positive Storm: Bonkers Dollars for Big Tech
description: In the Great Recession more than a decade ago, big tech companies hit a rough patch just like everyone else. Now they have become unquestioned winners of the pandemic economy.

title: Five Charged in Shooting of Lady Gagas Dog Walker
description: Five people have been arrested and charged in connection with a violent attack in February in which a man who was walking Lady Gagas French bulldogs in Hollywood was shot and two of the dogs were stolen, the Los Angeles police said on Thursday.

title: The Mayor Promises a Summer to Remember in New York. Can He Deliver?
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio declared on Thursday that New York City would fully reopen on July 1, conjuring up a tantalizing vision of a summer in which the nations largest city would throw open its doors and return to its prepandemic vibrancy.

title: Firing of U.S. Ambassador Is at Center of Giuliani Investigation
description: Two years ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani finally got one thing he had been seeking in Ukraine: The Trump administration removed the U.S. ambassador there, a woman Mr. Giuliani believed had been obstructing his efforts to dig up dirt on the Biden family.

title: 8 Indicted in Fraternity Hazing Death of Bowling Green Student
description: Eight people have been indicted in connection with the death last month of a sophomore at Bowling Green State University in Ohio, days after he had attended an off-campus fraternity event where school officials have said alleged hazing activity took place, prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Jill Corey, 85, Coal Miners Daughter Turned Singing Sensation, Dies
description: Jill Corey, a torch singer who soared to fame as a teenage television star in the early 1950s, at one point becoming one of Columbia Records top vocalists, died on April 3 at a hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 85.

title: Biden, in Georgia to Promote Economic Agenda, Visits Carter
description: President Biden visited former President Jimmy Carter, an old friend, as he traveled to Georgia on Thursday to pitch his $4 trillion economic agenda.

title: Michelle T. Boone Named President of Poetry Foundation
description: Michelle T. Boone, a former commissioner of cultural affairs for the City of Chicago, has been named president of the Poetry Foundation, nearly a year after the previous president resigned amid an intense outcry over the Chicago-based organizations perceived lack of commitment to social justice.

title: Senate Passes $35 Billion Water Bill, but Bigger Infrastructure Fights Loom
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a $35 billion measure to clean up the nations water systems, offering a brief moment of bipartisan cooperation amid deep divisions between the two parties over President Bidens much larger ambitions for a multitrillion-dollar infrastructure package.

title: Give Power to the Parents!
description: We live in a diverse country, where people have a lot of different preferences about how to live. For example, a 2016 Pew Research Center survey found that 59 percent of Americans believed children with two parents were better off if one parent stayed at home, but 39 percent thought children were just as well off if both parents worked.

title: President Bidens first formal address drew nearly 27 million viewers.
description: Nearly 27 million people watched President Bidens first formal address to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night, a large audience for television these days but a much smaller audience than similar speeches by other presidents, according to data from Nielsen.

title: Inside the Chauvin Jury Room: 11 of 12 Jurors Were Ready to Convict Right Away
description: Seated at tables six feet apart in a hotel conference room, 12 jurors scribbled letters on slips of paper to indicate how they were leaning on a murder charge against Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer on trial for killing George Floyd.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Alcohol, Covid Vaccine and Fat Fathers
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Mass Vaccination, Indias Covid-19 Escape Route, Poses a Giant Challenge
description: NEW DELHI  India is the worlds leading producer of vaccines, but over the past week it has also been the global leader in Covid-19 deaths, and it is not at all clear that the country can vaccinate itself out of the crisis.

title: How Is the G.O.P. Angling to Attack Biden?
description: As Senator Tim Scott delivered the Republican Partys rebuttal to President Bidens congressional address on Wednesday night, he had a big-picture question to confront: Where will the party go, in a time when it is split between two factions?

title: Sexual Assault Allegation Against Stringer Upends N.Y.C. Mayors Race
description: A bombshell sexual misconduct accusation against Scott M. Stringer pushed two major questions to the forefront of New York Citys mayoral race: Could the claim be corroborated, and how would Mr. Stringers campaign be affected by the allegation?

title: Palestinian Vote Delayed, Prolonging Split for West Bank and Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  When the Palestinian Authority called in January for parliamentary elections, many Palestinians hoped the vote  the first in the occupied territories since 2006  would revive Palestinian discourse, re-energize the independence movement and end a 14-year division between Palestinian leaders in the occupied West Bank and Gaza.

title: Stampede at Israel Religious Celebration Kills at Least 45
description: JERUSALEM  A stampede early Friday at a mountainside religious celebration in Israel that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews left at least 45 people dead and scores more injured.

title: America Is Brutal to Parents. Biden Is Trying to Change That.
description: When Patty Murray joined the Senate in 1993, one of the first bills she worked on was the Family and Medical Leave Act, which guaranteed 12 weeks of unpaid family leave for people who worked at companies with 50 or more employees.

title: N.F.L. draft order and picks: Here are the first round results.
description: 1. Jacksonville Jaguars  Trevor Lawrence (quarterback, Clemson)

title: With Zach Wilson, the Jets hope to end their decades-long QB search.
description: The Jets used the second pick in the draft to select Zach Wilson from Brigham Young, hoping that their long search for a franchise quarterback is over.

title: The Jets Try to Find a Quarterback  Again
description: Zach Wilson is the Jets latest attempt to solve a decades-long quarterback quandary: Theyre still trying to replace Joe Namath.

title: Pence, in his first speech since leaving office, speaks fondly of Trump.
description: In his first political speech since leaving office, former Vice President Mike Pence made clear that despite his grim falling out with former President Donald J. Trump, his days of trying to ingratiate himself to his former boss are far from over as he plots his political future.

title: Film Club: Sensations of Sound
Shake-Up at Covid Vaccine Manufacturer That Tossed Millions of Doses
description: WASHINGTON  Executives of Emergent BioSolutions, the Covid-19 vaccine manufacturer that was forced to discard up to 15 million doses because of possible contamination, reported a shake-up in leadership on Thursday and offered the most fulsome defense yet of the companys performance.

title: Florida Republicans Pass Voting Limits in Broad Elections Bill
description: MIAMI  Republicans in the Florida Legislature passed an election overhaul bill on Thursday that is set to usher in a host of voting restrictions in one of the most critical battleground states in the country, adding to the national push by G.O.P. state lawmakers to reduce voting access.

title: Quotation of the Day: Hauling Loads, With Pets at Their Side
description: Youre alone with yourself for long periods, and having a companion helps. A little happiness boost gets you through.

title: Corrections: April 30, 2021
description: An obituary on Sunday about Allon Schoener, the curator who organized the Metropolitan Museum of Arts 1969 show Harlem on My Mind, referred imprecisely to the paintings damaged as part of a protest against that show. Although initial news reports said that one of them was a Rembrandt, subsequent scholarship suggests that it was not. And a picture caption with the obituary misstated the given name of one of the people shown with Mr. Schoener. She is ALelia Nelson, not Lelia.

title: Biden will meet with South Koreas president on May 21.
description: President Biden will meet with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea in Washington on May 21, the White House announced on Thursday.

title: Appropriate Name for That Womans Husband
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  By the time you get to the Friday crossword, youve probably tussled with the early-week puzzles, sparred with the Wednesday grid and quite likely had your mind blown by the tricky Thursday.

title: Patriots take pocket-passer Mac Jones.
description: The New England Patriots watched from home as Tom Brady, their starter of 20 years, won his seventh Super Bowl with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, a blatant reminder that they needed to find a long-term solution at quarterback.

title: Idaho Lawmaker Accused of Raping an Intern Resigns
description: An Idaho lawmaker who the police say is the focus of a criminal investigation into allegations that he raped a 19-year-old female legislative intern last month resigned on Thursday  the same day that an ethics committee recommended that he be suspended.

title: Raiders take the fifth Alabama player drafted in the first round.
description: The Las Vegas Raiders, eager to replenish their offensive line, took Alex Leatherwood of Alabama at No. 17. Last year, Leatherwood (6-foot-5, 312 pounds) won the Outland Trophy, given to the best interior lineman in college football, after allowing just five sacks in 1,400 pass-block snaps. Yet the pick was something of a surprise, because higher-rated linemen were still available.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: As vaccinations march on in some of the worlds wealthiest countries, the crisis across Latin America  and in South America in particular  has taken an alarming turn for the worse, potentially threatening the progress made beyond its borders.

title: Giants fans seemed confused by receiver pick.
description: The Giants took receiver Kadarius Toney of Florida with the 20th pick to bolster the leagues second-worst offense. Toney (6 foot, 193 pounds) gives quarterback Daniel Jones an additional target downfield. Toney averaged 14 yards on his 70 catches last season, scoring 10 touchdowns. He is an elite tackle-breaker once he has the ball.

title: One Dead as Car Hits Motorbike and Outdoor Dining Structure in Queens
description: A 37-year-old man was fatally injured on Thursday evening when a car collided with his Yamaha motorbike and then crashed into an outdoor dining structure on a busy block of Astoria, Queens, the police said.

title: What to Know About Indias Coronavirus Crisis
description: A deadly second wave of coronavirus infections is devastating India, leaving millions of people infected and putting stress on the countrys already overtaxed health care system.

title: He Delivered for Me
description: For the first year of our relationship, I didnt know his name and didnt welcome his interruptions. I felt hassled by the unexpected knock on my window, which was necessary to get my attention because my apartment lacked a doorbell.

title: Triumph Review: Going to the Mat
description: Triumph tells the story of Mike (RJ Mitte), a high school senior in the 1980s who aspires to join the wrestling team. Because he has cerebral palsy, even adults who admire his resolve  like Coach Warren (Terrence Howard), who teaches Mike in a phys-ed class, and Mikes single father (Johnathon Schaech)  dont initially believe he can do it. Directed by Brett Leonard, the film was inspired by the experiences of its screenwriter, Michael D. Coffey.

title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
description: The horses for the 147th running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.

title: As Underclassmen Flood the N.F.L. Draft, Landing Places Dry Up
description: Clifton Duck may watch a bit of the N.F.L. draft this weekend, as he has in previous years. But he may not. Its everyones dream to go to the draft on TV, he said. But its a long, uncontrolled process, and you cant determine what happens.

title: Catch up: Amazons profit grows 220 percent as pandemic benefits Big Tech.
Its highway robbery: Teslas price increases on solar shingles irk customers.
description: Teslas solar ambitions date to 2015 when it announced that it would sell panels and home batteries alongside its electric cars. A year later, Elon Musk, the companys chief executive, promised that Teslas new shingles would turbocharge installations by attracting homeowners who found solar panels ugly.

title: Europes Recession Contrasts Economic Fortunes of U.S. Expansion
description: Contrasting economic data released on both sides of the Atlantic this week conveys a simple but powerful message: It pays to unleash enormous quantities of public money and vaccines in the face of a lethal, livelihood-destroying pandemic.

title: Its a Dogs Life  or Is It?
description: PAWCASSOBy Remy Lai

title: Stephen Colbert Can Relate to Ted Cruz
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: magnanimity
What is Australian Food? A New Cookbook Provides Some Answers.
description: What is Australian food? Is there even such a thing? These are questions Ive been asked so many times, and I admit to finding them incredibly frustrating. It doesnt help that the answers are not simple ones.

title: AstraZenecas vaccine has brought in $275 million in sales so far this year.
description: The vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford brought in $275 million in sales from about 68 million doses delivered in the first three months of this year, AstraZeneca reported on Friday.

title: In Opposing Climate and Diversity Proposals, Buffett Risks Looking Out of Step
description: Executives across corporate America, from Silicon Valley to Wall Street, have begun to heed calls from investors to disclose more about their companies actions on climate change and work force diversity. Warren E. Buffett isnt among them.

title: Frank Bowlings New Paintings Are Family Affairs
description: LONDON  On a recent afternoon behind a scruffy door in South London, remarkable alchemical transformations were taking place under the watchful eye of the painter Frank Bowling. Wearing industrial masks, a team of assistants brushed and dolloped ammonia, gold powder, acrylic gel and water onto a dripping canvas hung onto Bowlings studio wall.

title: This Is the End of Nuclear Energy in New York
description: Indian Point is the last nuclear power plant in the N.Y.C. region. Today marks the end of it's 59-year run.

title: Reflecting on a Lifetime of Reading and Other Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Would You Want to Live to 200?
description: From 1920 to 2020, the average human life span doubled. Medical and social advances such as the development of vaccines, germ theory and antibiotics, chlorinated water and pasteurized milk have reduced childhood deaths, mitigated diseases of old age and vastly prolonged life. The United Nations estimates that there were about 95,000 centenarians (people who live to 100) in 1990 and more than 450,000 in 2015.

title: Countdown
From Nigella Lawson to David Chang, Chefs Narrate the Stories Behind the Dishes
description: Puttering around the kitchen, Im almost always listening to an audiobook  often while consulting a recipe. But until recently, I had never listened to a cookbook, which seemed about as enticing as listening to someone read the phone book. Then I pressed play on COOK, EAT, REPEAT (HarperAudio, 11 hours, 42 minutes), by Nigella Lawson, narrated by the author in her plummy BBC English. I was transfixed.

title: New in Paperback: All Adults Here and Fire in Paradise
description: DOWN THE HIGHWAY: The Life of Bob Dylan, by Howard Sounes. (Grove, 608 pp., $22.) This 20th-anniversary edition celebrating Dylans upcoming 80th birthday includes a new chapter by the author on the past 10 years of Dylans life. No matter the time or place, Perry Meisel wrote in his 2001 review of the book in these pages, Dylan comes alive, strumming his guitar in a studio in Nashville or hurrying down Macdougal Street with the collar of his leather jacket turned up against the wind.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, April 30, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Not-So-Long-Distance Relationship Is Bridged by a Proposal
description: New Brunswick, N.J., is fewer than 50 miles from New York City, but for Dr. Marianne Jacob and Andrew Shenoy, who were married April 17 at the Basilica of St. Patricks Old Cathedral in Lower Manhattan, even that relatively small geographical gap was sometimes difficult to bear. From 2016 to 2019, the couple dated while separated by the Hudson River and three New Jersey counties.

title: A Restaurant Recommendation Closed the Distance
description: Julie Peak and Dr. Samuel Haywood have never lived in the same city.

title: Hows Our Girl?: On Loving a Foster Child and Letting Go
description: Cute baby, strangers said when they saw her.

title: Some Statues Tell Lies. This One Tells the Truth.
description: The United States is in a muddle over how to tell our history, stuck between an aggressive  revisionism that would leave few commemorative statues standing, and a stubborn clinging to all the founding myths, no matter how odious or inaccurate.

title: One Little Favor Before Their First Date
description: Dara Silverman knew Erik Leibovitz for all of 15 minutes after connecting on J-Swipe in July 2015, when he asked a question that caught her off guard.

title: At the Final Curtain Call, a Proposal
description: When Christopher Jones met Marissa Follo Perry at a bus stop, his infatuation with her was immediate. It was a big day for them both: the first day of kindergarten.

title: What We Lose When Only Men Write About Men
description: In The Aspern Papers, the Henry James novella of literary obsession, a biographer becomes fixated on a stash of secret letters belonging to an elderly woman who was once his subjects girlfriend. Abandoning all his moral scruples, he persuades her to take him in as her tenant and pretends to court her niece.

title: Bidens First 100 Days Would Make Trump Jealous
description: Joe Bidens inauguration, with its camp authoritarian light displays and general atmosphere of praetorian menace, was exactly the sort of swearing-in that his predecessor might have relished. Roughly a hundred days into Mr. Bidens presidency, it is hard to escape the feeling that his administration, too, could end up being one that Donald Trump will envy.

title: The Man With the Tiger Tattoo
description: Gabrielle Alyse Neimand caught a glimpse of a tiger the length of Micah Lennon McEachens forearm as they shared a tray full of cupcakes at their friends cupcake tasting in Los Angeles on Feb. 13, 2015.

title: Just Overwhelmed: When a School Restarts but Students Cant
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Think Outside the Brunch for Mothers Day
description: When Evie Ebert had her first child five years ago, she started noticing something interesting. Every Mothers Day, her social media feeds would be full of perfectly styled picnics and cooing captions like, Felt so celebrated today! But later, when she logged on to the private mom groups she was part of, the same women were telling a different story.

title: Surprise Family Reunion Videos Are Giving Us All the Feels
description: Josh Reynolds, who works in tech sales and lives in American Fork, Utah, got vaccinated without telling his extended family. Two weeks after his second shot, in the middle of April, Mr. Reynolds, 29, took his wife and younger brother, both also vaccinated, and 6-month-old daughter, to New Jersey. They rented a car at the airport and pulled up outside the house of his uncle, whom they hadnt seen since before the pandemic.

title: How Chuck Schumer Plans to Win Over Trump Voters
description: In his 100 days address this week, Joe Biden outlined his plans for a big, bold legislative agenda to come. He previewed a two-pronged economic package: the $2.25 trillion American Jobs Plan and the $1.8 trillion American Families Plan. He spoke about the need to pass universal background checks for firearms, comprehensive immigration reform, and the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.

title: They Want You Back at the Office
description: When Alice Fair flaunted north-facing views from the 48th floor of a skyscraper in Lower Manhattan, her audience was quiet. Most were on mute.

title: Theyre Trying to Bully Us: N.Y.U. Graduate Students Are Back on Strike
description: When Marwan Shalaby moved to New York from Egypt in 2019 to start an engineering Ph.D. at New York University, he had $700 in his bank account. He figured that would be enough to get settled.

title: How the Owner of a Doggie Day Spa Spends His Sundays
description: When Brian Taylor grooms his canine clients, sometimes he transforms their fur into all kinds of colors and shapes. Its just like hair, he said. Artists can turn hair into anything people want, and thats what I do for dogs.

title: Finding Love and All Its Quirks, Even If 2,654 Miles Away
description: In the summer of 2019, Stephen Paskey was on vacation, sitting in an Istanbul cafe, smoking a hookah. As much as he had hoped to meet a life partner by then, it just wasnt happening. In a few years, he thought, he would retire and maybe move to South America.

title: Where Should You Buy Your Books?
description: The last year has seen expanded options for buying books online, as more bookstores have developed websites, and e-commerce sites like Bookshop.org gain traction. But massive retailers like Amazon continue to dominate the bookselling business, and readers may be torn between the desire to support local bookstores and the convenience and price of online delivery giants. Here, booksellers and literary agents offer advice on how to evaluate your book buying options.

title: Pro-Biden Group to Begin Ad Campaign Promoting His Agenda in Swing States
description: WASHINGTON  A new group dedicated to promoting President Bidens ambitious agenda is beginning a multimillion-dollar ad campaign trumpeting his Covid recovery package and infrastructure proposal while contrasting Mr. Bidens low-key style with his bombastic predecessors.

title: Want to Move to Our Town? Heres $10,000 and a Free Bike.
description: Jennifer Hill Booker has spent much of her professional life on the road. Ms. Booker, 45, a chef and entrepreneur, is the author of two cookbooks, and her travels on the lecture circuit have taken her around the country  but always back to Atlanta, where she lived with her two children. Then, last year, with her daughters off at college, she realized there was nothing keeping her there. I am an empty nester looking for that next stage in my life, she said.

title: After the Pandemic and Protests, a British Rapper Spotlights Black Businesses
description: LONDON  For Aime Felone, whose childrens bookstore in London stocks tales with ethnically diverse characters, the Black Lives Matter protests last summer were, in a word, overwhelming.

title: Thunderous Plunges and Mossy Trickles: A Spring Guide to Waterfalls
description: As fall is to leaf-peeping, spring is to waterfall-watching, a seasonal pursuit now underway in the northern and higher regions of the United States.

title: Alexias Lifelong Nurse Has to Leave Her. Heres Why.
description: With one ear on the sound monitor linked to his daughters room, Joe Trimarchi sat at his dining room table in the Rosebank section of Staten Island. He was stuffing dozens of envelopes, hoping that one of them would land on the desk of a politician who might care. Mr. Trimarchi, 55, is a cashier in the billing department of Staten Island University Hospital, but what animates him is advocating for his daughter Alexia.

title: The Googleplex of the Future Has Privacy Robots, Meeting Tents and Your Very Own Balloon Wall
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Googles first office was a cluttered Silicon Valley garage crammed with desks resting on sawhorses.

title: The Many Ways Colleges Are Handling Covid-Complicated Graduations
description: Her first reaction after receiving the email from the University of Tampa announcing that commencement would be conducted online was to cry. Up and down the spine of Florida, larger colleges were announcing plans for in-person graduations  so why not hers? Then 22-year-old Allison Clark dried her tears and turned to Instagram, asking her followers: If Tampa hosted an in-person graduation, would they attend?

title: Now We Are United: Myanmars Ethnic Divisions Soften After Coup
description: The Myanmar militarys disinformation was crude but effective.

title: In Israel, dozens die in a stampede at a mass religious gathering held despite Covid warnings.
description: Israelis mourned on Friday the loss of life when a joyous pilgrimage that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews abruptly turned into a tragedy. And although the country was largely united in grief and shock, questions immediately arose about poor planning and possible negligence.

title: A Target Date for a Full Reopening in New York City
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Odessa, Part 4: Wellness Check
description: This episode contains references to mental health challenges, including eating disorders.

title: Odessa, Part 4: Wellness Check
description: This episode contains references to mental health challenges, including eating disorders.

title: Apples App Store Draws E.U. Antitrust Charge
description: LONDON  European Union regulators on Friday accused Apple of violating antitrust laws by imposing unfair rules and fees on rival music-streaming services that depend on the App Store to reach customers.

title: Indias passion turns grotesque: As the outbreak worsens, a cricket league plays on.
description: As plumes of smoke rose from cremation grounds, where bodies were arriving faster than they could be burned, teams of professional cricket players squared off under the lights of a cavernous stadium named for Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi.

title: How Politics Saves Lives
description: On a Sunday in July 2014, a man boarded a plane in Monrovia, Liberia, and flew to Lagos, Nigeria. He felt sick with a fever when the trip began and was in worse shape by the time he landed. The Nigerian authorities took him to a hospital, where doctors eventually diagnosed Ebola.

title: Vaccine Fan Fiction, Boom Time for Americas Forests and Political Apathy in N.Y.C.: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the stories.
